This is the scariest book I have read in my life. It is also one of the best books I have read. Although it is a fictional book, many of the petrifying things that occur in the book (a big government, propaganda, spying, police state, brainwashing) and the many methods through which these are achieved or maintained are things that have occurred in the past and that are occurring presently. This book is in my opinion, A WARNING; a warning against giving more power to the government and consequently less freedom to the individual. The environment in the book resembles the Soviet Union, Germany under the National Workers Socialist Party (Nazis), China under Mao, and most likely resembles North Korea the best. This is perhaps one of the best books you could read. Get it and SHARE IT!! I would also recommend reading Animal Farm by him also, before reading this one.

review_headline: As I was doing a great deal of driving I wanted to revisit some of ...
review_body: This is a classic and I had read many years ago as a freshman in college.  As I was doing a great deal of driving I wanted to revisit some of the classics I had read, but this time via CD during my extended driving periods.  The term Orwellian is part of our language, so there is no doubt this book has had a profound effect on the culture.  Much has been written on 1984 so I will not attempt to add to that, in a short review.  However I will say,  I had forgotten how truly dark and foreboding Orwell's presentation of a future, controlled by government, was.  Given that government and its tentacles via laws, and regulations has grown tremendously over the years, the book is well worth a read (or a listen if on CD).  But do not read it,  if you want something light or something uplifting, as it is neither.

review_headline: It may already be too late for reading this...
review_body:
The Centennial Edition, with the forward written by Thomas Pynchon, is the rare book that is absolutely critical reading for anyone living in a Democratic society. This is also a book that everyone imagines that they have read, even if they have never even had a copy on their bookshelves. It has been criticized for not following the template for a "well-written" novel, but it was not necessarily intended as such: Orwell was an essayist and a journalist first, passionate about what it means to be a civilized society.

There are lots of reviews here, so I won't go on at length. Suffice it to say that, after the Cheney Administration destabilized the Middle-East in order to create a perpetual state of war, it may already be too late to save Civilization.

Great book. Kind of the seminal dystopian work. Not sure how to describe it. There's a guy, Winston, who's beginning to question the new order. English socialism (IngSoc) has become the wool over the public's eyes so they may not see the truth about the ruling class and the constant state of "war". Language is being dismantled and replaced by NewSpeak, which is the ultimate imposition of the totalitarian ruling class. Conversation becomes relegated to terms such as "ungood", or doubleplusgood (excellent), sexcrime, goodest or gooder, etc. The point is to remove thoughtfulness and meaning and to further implicate individuality as a subversive attempt against the ruling class. Citizens are provided meager resources, such as stale rations of cigarettes or liberty vodka, tokens of the overarching govt that go nicely with the in house monitors through which Big Brother watches, at all times, even in the morning during mandatory mass calisthenics. People are allowed anger once a week during the 2 minutes hate in which the enemy of the state is broadcast, as though he has stolen the airwaves and wishes to impart hope to an otherwise hopeless populace. Winston meets a girl, goes with her places the upper class is not allowed, and bad things happen. He mingles with the idiotic proles who are nothing if not helpless products of the new order, relegated to poverty and a war torn infrastructure. Winston works in what could only be called the department of news, where he takes old newspaper articles and changes them to reflect the whims of the govt. In effect, he changes the past, so that it reconciles with the new present that has been made up on an whim.

This kind of story is all too familiar and often times it seems as though it is playing out right before our very eyes if in the most subtle ways. Hence the term "Orwellian", which tends to be used to describe a dark and forboding future. If you haven't read this book, you must..

George Orwell’s, Nineteen Eighty Four, is a riveting novel describing one man’s rebellion from dystopian society. Winston, the protagonist, lives his habitually boring life in the hopes he will find a person whom shares his belief towards society.
The society Winston lives in is run by the Party and ultimately “Big Brother”. The citizens are constantly monitored and taught to destroy individual thought. The details used by Orwell in describing the tactics of the Party to control society is not only knowledgeable, but also interesting. Orwell’s details create an altogether cohesive society with the main goal of total control.
Winston’s role in society is a worker in the Party’s Ministry of Truth. This section of society deals with the history of society, which is constantly altered. Most citizens seem to be oblivious; however, Winston questions the validity of society’s historical truths. Orwell’s character development of Winston as analytical and doubtful, drive me to question the honorability of the society which I live in today.
Later in the novel, Winston is faced with difficult decisions based on trust and intuition. These choices will either help or hurt him in his fight to change the corrupt society he lives in. Winston must trust his instincts in order to begin change in the society. Will Winston achieve his goal to reinvent the controlling society or will he die trying?

I'm not a fan of Orwell's writing style but the story is one for the ages.  Big government run a muck. Big brother watching your every move.  Freedoms gradually taken away until you have none left.  It's a timeless tale which is why it still popular all these years after it was written.

This book goes deeper & is more challenging than Animal Farm so I would recommend Animal Farm before reading this book. Even though it really makes you think it's wrapped up in a good story. The ending was spot on. It's a little tougher than Animal Farm but I still loved it

review_headline: Big Brother Says Two Plus Two Equals Five
review_body:
Welcome to Oceania. Our guide to this world is Winston Smith, a member of The Party who works at the Ministry of Truth making sure that all documents conform to The Party line. And in this socialist vision of the world, The Party, as embodied by Big Brother, is all powerful.

However, Winston is old enough to have vague memories of life before The Party took over England. While he outwardly tows the line, he is hoping that at some point The Party can be overthrown. As he starts a forbidden affair with Julia, it looks like his hopes might come to be. Do they have hope of overthrowing the government? Or is Big Brother really all powerful?

I know I read this book back in high school, but that was a few years ago, so I decided it was time to read it again. As a novel, it isn’t that good. There are long, preachy passages and it’s easy to let your mind start to wander. Yes, some world building is needed, but entirely too much of it takes place.

However, in a study of how a totalitarian government can take over power and never let it go, this book is chilling. And before you shake it off and say, “That would never happen here,” look around. I see it happening on both sides of the spectrum, and politicians on both sides encouraging it. We need to start heeding the warning that Orwell put in this book before we become part of Oceania.

So read this book. Think about it. And figure out how you will keep the government from turning into Big Brother.

Orwell's most famous work, "Nineteen Eighty Four", written in 1949 is still as gripping, poignant and terrifying as it must have been over 60 years ago. My review is for the unabridged audio CD, skillfully read by Simon Prebble. Orwell describes a dystopian society in the country of Oceania, in which war is permanent, government surveillance is widespread, individualism and all forms of self expression are suppressed, and "big brother" is watching. Though this novel has been on every "Top 100" reading list as well as high school and college curriculums for decades, somehow I had put off reading it until now. I was quite surprised at how relevant it still is, ensuring that it will remain on required reading lists for many decades to come.

The main character, Winston Smith, works at the Ministry of Truth, as part of a team that is constantly rewriting history to suit the purposes of the current party line. No one is sure who "big brother" really is, or even if such a person exists. Citizens are constantly programmed with "double think" phrases such as "Ignorance is strength", "war is peace", and "freedom is slavery". They fear the thought police who will punish them severely for not adhering to party teachings, even in their thoughts. Society is plagued by constant shortages, scarcity and hardships, primarily due to constant wars. The Machine believes in constant warfare to get rid of materials that might make the masses comfortable and complacent. The Party's main purpose is to mold the consciousness of the masses, and was described at one point as a "boot stamping on a human face."

The themes of nationalism, censorship and surveillance are just as relevant today as they were over 60 years ago, ensuring that this novel will remain in the forefront of literature for a long time to come. It's not an easy book to read, since the deprivation, brainwashing and torture are hard to endure. However, I suspect that I will read it again and again because of the many levels of meaning and message.endure. However, I suspect that I will read it again and again because of the many levels of meaning and message.

I first read this book in spring of 1967 as a college sophomore. I thought it was interesting and easy to read. I thought it was a tale about a nation where government had gone to the extreme - a socialist bureaucracy. I never suspected that government could get this intrusive in a democratic-republic, the most freedom loving nation in the world!

However, I now wonder if we weren't on our way to bloated, over-powering government. And I wonder if socialism and bureaucracy haven't completely taken hold, entrenched large powerful government, unconcerned with individual rights??? Orwell… a genius or a prophet? Everyone should read this book accompanied by a copy of the Bill of Rights!

review_headline: This book isn’t immediately accessible. You need to stick with it.
review_body:
I’ve been wanting to read this book for years. I was fascinated by the idea of it when I first learned about it in high school. The futuristic world was intriguing, and to know that the often-used phrase of "Big Brother" comes from this book, made it even more appealing.

I remember hearing in high school that Orwell was writing this novel in 1948 (even though it was later published in 1949). Therefore, when choosing the year for his dystopian future, he flipped the final two numbers to create 1984. There are so many interesting science fiction ideas developed by Orwell (the Thought Police and Telescreens, just to name a couple).

One warning for readers, though. This book isn’t immediately accessible. You need to stick with it, and plow through some of the parts that seem to be dragging on. The book is split into three parts, and while I felt engaged during Parts 2 and 3, Part 1 took me a long time to get through.

FINAL RATING: 3.5 stars out of a possible 5

SLIGHT SPOILERS:

This is not a happy book. This is not a fun adventure. As opposed to modern dystopian fiction, there isn't a hero that leads a rebellion against a corrupt ruler. Instead, this book is about total loss of self in response to a tyrannical government. Instead of a grand, far-reaching story, this book explores how living in a dystopian world slowly tears a man down, and strips him of his very identity. The end of this man's story was truly depressing.
very good

This novel is a must read for every high school senior in America and should be a highly recommended "must read" for all college graduates.  How the author Orwell could predict in 1948 what our governments are doing worldwide is so uncanny its frightening.  I only wish "we the people" would take notice and attempt to begin changing our government back the way our Constitution says BY LAW what we are suppose to do.  Sadly, this is not the case. If there's any true democracy remaining a hundred years from now people/citizens will look back at this novel and say:  "They were warned and still did not pay attention."

review_headline: The creeping present or, worse, a portent of the future ?
review_body:
Orwell's vision of the state machine assuming the ability to rob each of us of our individuality to ensure conformity is pessimistic and yet, at times, all too much of a reality in various parts of our world in 2015.

The mayhem for individuals is compounded by the fact that the state comes to control not only our lifestyles but also even our individual thoughts and emotions which otherwise make up the difference between each of us so that we become, ultimately, no more than flesh-clad automatons. The Ministry of Love would be laughable - if the reality was not horrific - and apart from the intrusiveness of the state's minions, together with cameras everywhere and the possibility of eventual genetic manipulation, such a state could too easily emerge from Orwell's insights under a tyrant.

review_headline: Excellent read - everyone needs to read this book.
review_body: Wonderfully written, and unfortunately as relevant today as it was when it was written.
Great book. Very eye opener.

Winston Smith lives in England under a totalitarian government called \\"the Party\\". Winston works in The Ministry of Truth as a person who alters the history of the world. But one day, Winston meets up with a lady named Julia and they commit their lives to the Brotherhood, an anti-government group. It goes well for Winston and Julia, until they become outlaws wanted by the Party.

1984 is an excellent book. The author of Animal Farm and this novel,George Orwell created a thrilling and intense story. He creates a feeling to the reader that something is wrong with this \\"government\\". The government in Winston's society doesn't want people to know about the past.If they do, they may rebel. So, in response, they alter the present so Winston's government can look to them as superior. In effect, citizens of \\"Oceania\\", where Winston lives, are completely oblivious to what really has happened in the past. Moreover, the government wants people to know what they're doing so that they don't rebel. For example, there are laws against \\"thoughtcrime\\". \\"Thoughtcrime\\" is a crime committed in your thoughts like having hatred for the Party, but in secret. Another example of this is the government sets up cameras and microphones everywhere so they can bust people for \\"thoughtcrime\\". One of the goals of Winston's government is to take over the world and enforce their law around the world. The man at the top of all of this is Big Brother. He's the supreme ruler of Oceania. He's the one in charge of everything; the Party, the agencies and his people. While living in this world, Winston learns of the Brotherhood, an anti-Party agency. he decides to join this agency because he feels that something is wrong about his government and he wants to change it and give everybody their freedoms back.

When 1984 was first published in 1949, it generally got excellent reviews. Some of these reviews came from V.S. Pritchett, P.H. Newby, and Bertrand Russell. But a negative review ofthe book came from Edward Shanks, a book reviewer for the Sunday Times. Shanks claimed that 1984 \\"Breaks all records for gloomy vaccination\\". I do not agree with Shanks's review of 1984. I think it's a great book with a lot of adventure, suspense, and action. So all in all, it's a great book and I encourage everybody to read it.

review_headline: Deviates corrected for their own good
review_body:
In a society that has eliminated many imbalances, surplus goods, and even class struggle, there are bound to be deviates; Winston Smith is one of those. He starts out, due to his inability to doublethink, with thought crime. This is in a society that believes a thought is as real as the deed. Eventually he graduates through a series of misdemeanors to illicit sex and even plans to overthrow the very government that took him in as an orphan.

If he gets caught, he will be sent to the "Ministry of Love" where they have a record of 100% cures for this sort of insanity. They will even forgive his past indiscretions.

Be sure to watch the three different movies made from this book:
1984 (1954) Peter Cushing is Winston Smith
1984 (1956) Edmond O'Brien is Winston Smith
Nineteen Eighty-Four (1984) John Hurt is Winston Smith
All is well.

review_headline: you are better off watching the movie which does a pretty good ...
review_body: This book, published in 1949, is about a futuristic society in 1984 “where only animals and proletarians are free” and the government’s slogans are: “War is peace/Freedom is slavery/Ignorance is strength.” This totalitarian regime takes place in Oceana, former England, where all the citizens are brainwashed around the clock propaganda broadcasted by TVs placed in the living rooms of houses. TV  screens also allow the government officials spy on the  residents  around the clock. The government vaporizes people of their choosing for the reasons of their own by executing them and erasing any records indicating they once had existed. Also all the records including newspapers or TV broadcast scripts are rewritten in accordance with the reality of the present. Not only the subject matter of the book is so bleak, making one think when he wrote this book the author must have suffered from major depression since no situation could be this helpless and hopeless, the writing style of the book doesn’t help the matter either. If you are curious about this classic, you are better off watching the movie which does a pretty good job and last less than two hours instead of spending several days reading this book.

review_headline: A book that should be required reading in every HS in every democracy
review_body: George Orwell wrote this futuristic novel if I recall correctly after he came home to England after having fought against Franco's fascists in the Spanish civil war. It is about the threat to humanity posed by dictatorships that will seize power and use secret thought police to prosecute political dissidents for thought crimes. Orwell was an English socialist he fought Franco's fascists but he also if I recall correctly barely made it out of Spain alive one step ahead of Stalin's KGB assassins. I argue that Orwell when he wrote this book was trying to warn all of humanity about the dangers of Dictatorships Fascist and Communist that wrought such genocide murder and havoc in the last century.

I came to this book in a round-about way. Two points of interest led me to 1984.

#1. I had always been curious about cults, mind control, etc. So awhile back I picked up a book entitled \\"Raven\\" about Jim Jones. As I was reading, I found myself stupefied with my mouth hanging open like a idiot. How is this possible? What strange psychological techniques are involved? I subsequently bought and read every psychological book on mind control I could find. Now, with my own informal education, I think I have a good grasp of the phenomenon.

#2. The recent exposure of the activities of the IRS in targeting conservative groups. I thought, this is an obvious totalitarian tactic: \\"Silence the Opposition.\\" But why has this not resulted in outrage (unlike Watergate)? How can we accept, with complacency, a brazen attempt at domination? Have we all forgotten the essential principals America was founded on? I subsequently bought and read every major book on totalitarian states I could find, in an attempt to understand how the IRS affair was largely ignored by the populace.

Since a vast majority of these books refer to Orwell's 1984, I figured a fictional, fantasy account would add to my understanding of both these strange phenomenon. My supposition was correct. What many of my formal, technical books do not do (rightly so), is express the human experience with emotional impact...love, tragedy, denial, anger, etc.

The genius of this book is how it expresses the individual human experience of living is a totalitarian world.
The frightening part of this book is that it could easily come true. The methods of control described are very real. Obviously used in Nazi Germany and the USSR. In fact, the whole story of 1984 may be taking place right now, IN THE REAL WORLD of North Korea!

The cult/mind control aspect showed me the methods, the IRS affair showed me how easily a totalitarian state can begin, and 1984 put it all togetherin a humanistic, thought provoking story. If this book doesn't turn you into a libertarian, or at least get you thinking about it.....nothing will.

Update: After reading this one, I highly recommend \\"We The Living\\" by Ayn Rand for a more realistic and equally thought-provoking read.
Yes, don't think it wont happen....we are living it right now...time to buy more ammo and stock up, never too soon.

I haven't read this book since my high school days, and even then, I never read the entire book. It is a cultural classic, but a pretty horrifying check on reality - for Orwell does not mince his words - this is raw, far more horrifying than any Hollywood \\"horror\\" film because his book depicts plausible reality. He presses home, paragraph after paragraph, page after page, with the subtlety of a sledgehammer, the future we would face were we to permit Big Brother to become a reality. I have not checked school curricullums lately, to see if this book is on the required reading list - but if not, that is a fatal error because 1984 is a manual, a text book for the anti-Christ of freedom - and required education for anyone living in a society which is edging towards ultra-surveillance, such as our own. I marvel at Orwell's ability, in 1949, to piece together such a picture and something of a vigilance. But I warn you, reading this book is not for the faint hearted - it's grimy, right down there at the gutter of humanity's low - slaves to a system.
Written many moons ago. The truth is forming throughout the world. Perhaps the true year should be 2014 or 2024.

review_headline: Obsessive overkill bogs down brilliant dystopia
review_body:
George Orwell was the great prophet of totalitarianism. His Homage to Catalonia (1938) sounded an early warning about the nature of the Soviet Communists in its depiction of how they attempted to subvert the Spanish Republican government even at the cost of helping the fascists in the short term. Animal Farm (1945) was a dissection of how the idealistic Russian revolution was co-opted by Stalinist totalitarians. Then came 1984, Orwell's culminating work, published just before his death of tuberculosis in early 1950.

Unfortunately, I also think that his impending death impelled Orwell to run off the rails a bit in his dystopian vision. While the first part of the book is brilliant in its depiction of a society controlled and manipulated by an all-powerful state—read The Gulag Archipelago to see just how closely Orwell's fictional Oceania tracks the real-world Soviet state under Stalin—the second part following Winston Smith's arrest goes way overboard as Orwell seek to make a philosophical point about the subjection of the total man and also gross out readers as much as possible about just how horrible a world he can create. But to achieve this, Orwell has to sacrifice the integrity of his story.

The whole premise of the first part was to give readers a disturbingly plausible vision of how a populace can be made to submit and acquiesce to its servitude to the state. The perpetual surveillance through the two-way video screens (creepily analogous to GPS trackers in today's electronic gadgets), the never-ending happy-talk propaganda, the bread-and-circuses mollification of the "proles" (what we today call "low information voters" in a delicious bit of real-life newspeak) and the realization that the best way to control a population is to keep them hopped up on a crusade in which "we're all in it together" (which is why governments today are eternally declaring "war" on everything from drugs to iliteracy)—all brilliant and brilliantly depicted.

But then Winston Smith gets arrested and the verisimilitude vanishes. First of all, the whole idea that a police state would bother to make sexual indiscretion a capital crime is ridiculous (unless it has a theological basis such as in Medieval Christianity or modern Iran). Yes, I get it that it highlights Orwell's argument that a totalitarian state seeks to destroy everything human or individual in its subjects, but I think Aldous Huxley was on a much sounder ground in Brave New World where promiscuity was not only legal but encouraged. If you want to devastate the individual/spiritual integrity of a populace, it's better to turn them into beasts thant monks.

But my biggest criticism is how the narrative runs aground during O'Brien's ongoing interrogation and torture of Smith. For this to be plausible, we have to believe that this high muckety-muck in the Oceania hierarchy would have spent the last seven years minutely tracking the activities of a mid-level worker drone, and then spent considerable state resources to capture and torture this individual over an extended period. And for what? So that he can destroy "the last man" as Smith is unconvincingly termed? The conclusion to be drawn seems to be that once the last independent thinker is snuffed out, there won't be any more of them. If only, says ever tyrant in history. Frankly, O'Brian comes off as an obsessive loon and if I were Big Brother, I would seriously consider getting him off the payroll for pursuing a private agenda with state resources. Who knows what he'll fixate on next.

Yes, I understand that Orwell's point was to show as brutally as possible the stamping out of individualism, but he could have saved the tedious lectures O'Brien (and Emanuel Goldstein through the extended excerpts from his book) foists on poor Smith (and the reader) and simply continued to show life in Oceania. That to me was by far the most compelling part ofthis book.

review_headline: A book that should be read regularly
review_body:
I have read 1984 over a dozen times in my 53 years. There are very few books I have read that often, certainly Fahrenheit 451 and perhaps Animal Farm. 1984 is a book I need to read every now and then just to make sure I don't forget the warnings in it and to enable me to see how much of what Orwell warned us about has already come to pass.

It's an important book. I don't use the term lightly. Masquerading as a science fiction novel we have a clear view of our time and what's awaiting us bleakly presented to us by a wise, clairvoyant man.

I disagree with some reviewers who feel the book was inspired solely by totalitarian Russia. The book was written in 1948 and well after Orwell's experience in Spain fighting with other idealists in the International Brigade but he put a lot of his Spanish experiences into 1984. If you read Orwell's Homage to Catalonia (highly recommended and interestingly regarded as the best history of the Spanish civil war by many) you can see how he discovered that there is no real truth; what masquerades as truth can be changed at will and varies from place to place, from hour to hour. Certain streets in Barcelona changed their alliances in the civil war from week to week and had no memory that there had ever been a change. Orwell came to help the Spanish and ended up being on a wanted list because of the unorganised nature of civil war.
His idealism was replaced with cynicism and a clear capacity to see through the smoke and mirrors and most importantly, a talent for sharing his wisdom with us.

I sometimes fantasise about the result if George Orwell and Ray Bradbury had one day got together to write a book......

This book is great and I would recommend reading it in conjuction with [[ASIN:B004W0YBZY WE]], [[ASIN:0060850523 Brave New World]], and maybe even Animal Farm. Huxley wrote his book in 1932 and Orwell's book \\"1984\\" (that was written in 1949) carried the genre to greater heights, which is why \\"1984\\" is the most known of the mentioned 3 books.

In \\"Brave New World,\\" Huxley successfully predicts the future of genetic engineering. There are no parents or families, death no longer elicits emotional reactions, and men and women are expected to have with innumerable sexual partners. The society is genetically altered into class divisions known as Alpha, Beta, Gamma, Delta, and Epsilon. Alphas are the most intelligent, have the most important jobs, and have the most free will. In contrast, Epsilon's are the least intelligent, have the worst jobs, and have the least amount of free will. The society displayed is one that needs entertainment to be happy and live for a drug known as soma, which removes all pain and makes them \\"happy.\\"

\\"WE\\" is most like 1984 in the prediction of how the future will be. They both see people losing their personal identity and becoming just a number. \\"WE\\" is written in first person, as a journal entry of D-503's life. He lives in a city that is surrounded by a green wall and in a society where people have no names, just numbers, and follow a strict schedule for work, sleep, leisure activities, and even sex. The journal explains who he is, his daily schedule, and eventually gives a detailed account of his inner thoughts as he wrestles with the idea that all is not as it appears with the world. All this begins when he meets I-303 for the first time. (That is all I will say - no spoilers here.)

\\"1984\\" centers around one character, Winston. Winston is living in the UK which is under the control of BIG BROTHER. In this society, one must do, think, say, and appear as if they believe and follow what BIG BROTHER wants. Cameras are everywhere, even inside houses. Kids report parents for deviating from what the \\"Party\\" wants. Fellow citizens look for small changes in your face or activities that might be evidence of \\"thought crimes.\\" In this society, one must only think it to be convicted of the crime. As Winston lives his life, he hides a secret from everyone hoping one day to find others who do not agree with the doings of the \\"Party.\\" He meets a woman, and they embark on a journey to find the underground resistance that is against BIG BROTHER. Their lives will be forever changed because of this decision.

I think that all of these works are relevant today to read or re-read. I would recommend these books to anyone. Happy reading!Cameras are everywhere, even inside houses. Kids report parents for deviating from what the \\"Party\\" wants. Fellow citizens look for small changes in your face or activities that might be evidence of \\"thought crimes.\\" In this society, one must only think it to be convicted of the crime. As Winston lives his life, he hides a secret from everyone hoping one day to find others who do not agree with the doings of the \\"Party.\\" He meets a woman, and they embark on a journey to find the underground resistance that is against BIG BROTHER. Their lives will be forever changed because of this decision.

I think that all of these works are relevant today to read or re-read. I would recommend these books to anyone. Happy reading!

review_headline: Plot - 3, Characters - 3, Theme - 5, Voice - 3, Setting - 4, Overall - 4
review_body:
1) Plot (3 stars) - In a future where you're every move is watched for unorthodoxy, one man dares to question and in so doing learns the truth about his society. But at what price? It was a good plot, though at times it moved a bit slow, and in many parts it was told in lecture as opposed to character discovery or dialogue.

2) Characters (3 stars) - Winston is the nervous lead, gingerly stepping into more and more truth and danger. Julia is the rambunctious female interest who boldly yanks him forward. The two leads were good vehicles to push the plot, but neither was particularly memorable.

3) Theme (5 stars) - This is the classic exploration of life under a modern police state, of what happens when people's fears cause them to give up their freedoms, and how those in power will continue to manipulate those fears to retain power. It successfully predicted Eastern Europe under the Soviet empire, Mao's Cultural Revolution, and modern day North Korea. Some like to also hold it up as an example of where the US is heading, but I find that connection a bit more tenuous. Certainly the technology now exists to create much of the surveillance and data manipulation apparatus described in the book, but in Western countries like the US that same technology has been democratized, spread into the hands of the many, a counterbalancing phenomenon that was not prognosticated nor explored in the book.

4) Voice (3 stars) - The prose was fine, but I didn't mark any sentences as particularly poetic, beautiful, or insightful. Also, I found certain sections to be a bit \\"lecturey.\\"

5) Setting (4 stars) - Orwell successfully transported me into the mood of this dystopia--the greyness, the shuffling hunchback people nervously checking over their shoulders, the hopelessness of being trapped under the thumb of Big Brother.

6) Overall (4 stars) - I'd recommend 1984 for the exploration of the dangers of the police state and the darkfeeling of dystopia, though I wished there was more to the plot and characters.

As my friend Ben said recently about Animal farm, \\"The book is good in what it is about but those damn pigs made me so mad.\\" Yup, ditto Ben. I felt 1984 had some interesting ideas and although for something like that to really happen is extreme, sometimes making something extreme brings out a point. Left unchecked the Government could easily absorb more responsibilities and when the Government starts fearing its own people, maybe there is some cause for concern. I feel this book is even more relevant with recent events coming to light about the NSA and Government spying, not just on its own inhabitants but the world as well. So how do we fight government take over and maintaining our individuality? The answer is simple, by reading books and having sex. I like this plan!

I purchased this as a companion gift to my brother to go with a copy of Animal Farm that I gave him at the same time. The gift was the result of a discussion we had about current events. He loves Orwell but had not read 1984. Love Orwell!

We've all heard of \\"1984\\", or at least, the term \\"Orwellian\\" (interesting note: George Orwell was his pen name). I always thought of it as some sort of dystopian, apocalyptic and futuristic take about our future, which is a bleak one with \\"big brother\\" always watching and freedom being an illusion. And yup, that's what this book is about. It's brutal, depressing, and brilliant in its own way. One of the things that astounds me the most is that Orwell wrote this so long ago, yet it still resonates strongly. Even the technology he talks about seems very similar to what we have now. I enjoyed the book, but I do think it has its weaknesses. The first is that there is no hope. None at all. You never even feel it. The second is that none of the characters are likable. Perhaps even worse, you never really know any of them. So even though it's a brilliant piece of work, there's a very bland aspect to it.

7/10.

Much of NSA's previous work has been criticized as disingenuous, bland and excessively brief, but the agency seems to have completely reinvented itself in its latest work, \\"1984: Blueprint for a Stronger Democracy.\\" The book details a utopian society in which a political dissident is transformed by a series of interactions with his benevolent totalitarian government and in the end comes to see that he does, in fact, love the state's omnipresent dictator, known as Big Brother.

I have no doubt that we are making a great deal of progress in making this vision a reality, as government surveillance grows ever more powerful. Political dissidents might finally start to keep their views to themselves if they realize that their online activity is being monitored, and that inappropriate use of the internet will result in a visit from the government. But reading NSA's latest work left me deeply troubled, for it is clear that American citizens still have excessive freedom to communicate with each other. I can only hope that Edward Snowden's recent revelations about the scope of NSA's surveillance is just the tip of the iceberg.

There are few other classics so relevant today as this one.

Orwell was a prophet. Having witnessed the bolshevik terror in Russia, this was his 'wake up call' to the world. He was chillingly accurate - just look around.

review_headline: I Hope This Never Comes True
review_body:
That George Orwell really knows how to scare the pants off a person. He wrote about angered animals revolting and taking over a farm, and now it's an all-encompassing, all-powerful government that controls every facet of its constituents' lives, right down to their very thoughts.

1984 was primarily written during the years 1947 and 1948 and was published in June of 1949. By the year 1989, Orwell's novel had been translated into 65 different languages, more than any other English-language novel at that time. Throughout it's entire publication history it has been either banned or legally challenged somewhere in the world. In 2005, Time magazine listed it in its \\"100 best English-language novels from 1923-2005.\\" It was also listed at number 6 in the \\"Modern Library 100 Best Novels.\\"

1984 follows the life of Winston Smith as he struggles to conform. We get a first-hand look at the fear and distrust that rules his every thought and action. Reading 1984 will definitely help you to appreciate your own situation, no matter how bad it may seem. And if you're unclear on just exactly what a dystopian novel is, this is it. This is the book that defines the genre.

Frank Muller is one of my very favorite audiobook narrators, and a perfect fit for 1984. His grit and solemnity serve to augment the funerary feel of the audiobook. Muller has been a stage and television actor, but is most famous for his audiobook narration having narrated hundreds of novels. He died in 2008 after many years of complications from a motorcycle accident in 2001.

I think everyone should read 1984 at least once, and that time you were forced to read it in school doesn't count. This is a good reminder of how things might have been, if history had turned out just a little bit different. And any audiobook narrated by Frank Muller is worth a listen.
This book is scary because it depicts much of what this broken world is coming to. It makes one wonder what can be done to fix this situation.
I did not get the book I ordered, instead I got the book Artemis Fowl: The Opal Deception by Eoin Colfer

review_headline: Since recent exposure of the  extent to which our personal data are being used, my family will be passing this around.
review_body: My entire family is interested in reading this book since they became aware of the extent to which our personal data is being accessed.  Having the "honor" of being the oldest in the family, I am familiar with the storyline after having seen either a movie or TV programs many years ago featuring Edmund O'Brien.  It is a compelling story and makes one wonder what else is in store for us.

review_headline: Good quality; a MUST READ for everyone.
review_body:
The quality is good. If you haven't read it, it's necessary reading. Everyone today is worried about Government Spying and Privacy. You'll often hear the words: Orwellenian, Big-Brother, etc. If you use these words or have said them; you need to have read this novel. It's as contemporary for today as it was for the day written.

We read it in high school in 1976--- and I remember when 1984 came and went and nothing happened. But, NOW it's happened just like the book. Big Brother is here, and He are US!!! This will open your eyes Wider. I'm re-reading it after many years.

Don't short yourself--- readers of all ages; This is a MUST READ.

Although I read this book years ago, I decided I needed a refresher since much is being said about it in the news today.  My husband and I drove from CA to CO this summer, and we took this little book along.  WOW!  We kept repeating, "That's happening NOW!  That's happening right NOW!"  And with all the current NSA stuff in the news, all readers can't help but see the connections.  The scary thing is that Orwell wrote this book in 1949.  How did he know?  What link did he have to our current situation?  That's the freaky part.  Anyway, listening to the book made our drive a pleasure.  We also listened to Atlas Shrugged by Ayn Rand and would recommend this as a companion to 1984.  But be prepared:  Atlas Shrugged is 50 disks long!  Still... riveting!  :)

Read this book many years ago, and found it very interesting, especially for the time it was written!
This one was for my Grandson, who had never heard about it.
Excellent condition. A must read for all Americans. When this book was written I wonder if Orwell had a dream of things to come.
Prophetic.  Will make you question whether democracy can be found any where today and what real freedom there is in so-called free states.
Bought this as a replacement for the original copy I donated to children in Africa; I sure hope they got to read it. Very important book.

Booked received fast enough and in good condition. Second time I read it , over 35 years later.
You can see more than one government described here. Amazing he wrote this before the 50's!

With the latest revelations of NSA intelligence-gathering techniques, a friend of mine suggested that I pick up this book. What shocked me was the accuracy with which Orwell predicted government intrusion into daily life....in 1948!!! Orwell imagines people sitting in front of screens every day that monitor their daily activity. He sees the ability to track and listen-in on people on the move as another tool in the pocket of the government. Through our smartphones and computers, the government today has intruded into almost every aspect of our lives.

There are some further parallels can be drawn as well. Orwell saw one factor in the political decline as the loss of \\"external reality,\\" namely that reality is objective and observable. Such a concrete philosophical notion of reality has been replaced by the current postmodern subjective reality where 2+2 *can* equal 5, if that's what I think it equals. In today's society where there is no sin or goodness but in what you determine to be such, there is but one small step towards an Orwellian society. If the locus of what determines reality shifts from the person to the state. And perhaps much of this has already happened behind our backs. Because most of us have lost our notions of objective external reality through the public education system of our nation.

And then there's the issue of history. In an age where we're moving more and more towards reliance on cloud-based electronic mediums, erasure of history is truly only a keystroke away. Oral traditions and histories have been exchanged for written ones. Written ones have been exchanged for electronic ones. And the end result is that most in our society knows less about history than ever. Contrary to Emerson and other writers and thinkers who have seen history (and living in light of history) as weak or sub-human, Orwell sees history in its rightful primacy. If we don't understand the past, we can't possibly understand the present. The richness of history leads us to the greatness of religion, the beauty of art, and the heights of science. Ignoring history leads only to self-destruction, enslavement, and loss of beauty.

I would suggest pairing this read with Huxley's equally dystopian \\"A Brave New World\\" for maximum effect. Readers should be advised that there are several depictions of sex and torture in some sections of this book. The literary and historical significance of the work, however, makes it worth reading for the discerning adult.

Let me close this review by saying that this book doesn't leave me as doom and gloom as I suppose it has left many other readers. While I believe that man is capable of great evil like that portrayed in the book, I believe that things are not meant to be the way they are. In spite of our notions of a subjective reality, the effects of self-serving politicians, poverty, famine, war, greed and so on strike us all as wrong because they really are fundamentally wrong. We long for wrongs to be made right and for an objective, external reality that we can hang on to. And nothing can take that feeling out of us. Even if someone could use our deepest fears against us, we still cannot repress that testimony. And it is because I know that the world is broken (as Orwell warns), I know it can be fixed.The richness of history leads us to the greatness of religion, the beauty of art, and the heights of science. Ignoring history leads only to self-destruction, enslavement, and loss of beauty.

I would suggest pairing this read with Huxley's equally dystopian \\"A Brave New World\\" for maximum effect.
