Even if someone could use our deepest fears against us, we still cannot repress that testimony. And it is because I know that the world is broken (as Orwell warns), I know it can be fixed.
I bought this book on the recommendation of a friend and I have to say, I'm happy I did!  Such a great book!

review_headline: They left out most of Chapter 6...Censorshiping????
review_body: My title says it all. Read the book the audio leaves out most of \\"Ministry of Truth\\" buy the book to get the WHOLE story.
In light of the government overeach today I wanted to re-read George Orwell.  It has been very enlightening to read.
I bought it for school use. Great quality, a good book for casual reading or academic use. Nice cover design and paper quality.

Mandatory read for every us citizen. Used to be required reading on every high school reading list, but due to the totalitarian thought police ,just like the ones conceived of in this futuristic warning, some liberal schools have shyed away from it doe to political political correctness.this book is a warning to every American.this could be you, our country, our society,if we relinquish out freedoms.if I had to choose the one most thought provoking book I have ever read or taught this is it!

The title draws you in, but in the end, it really doesn't matter. Did you know that Orwell was going to name the book 1948? In the end, he named it 1984 (a play on numbers perhaps?). The title is just that, a title, but how you feel about the government and life will never be the same after reading this book. And how you feel about being in your own home next to a television will never be the same either.

I read this a few months ago and you know those books that you want to throw across the room when you are done, the ones that have penetrated into your heart and cut it to shreds? This is such a book. Many say it's recommended reading, well I guess it is, but it's also a book you NEED to read so you can add it to the short list of those that remain with you always.

Oh, the sadness is creeping up. I won't give away the ending, but let's just say that you will feel outrage and a terrible sort of emptiness. Let it sink in and know that this book touches on what is real, not just some sort of imagined nightmare. Take care and think happy thoughts.

review_headline: This is not an instruction manual!
review_body:
Note to US Congress and house of representatives:

This is a fictional book, not an instruction manual.
I suggest you read this one instead:
[[ASIN:B000ZTI0JO Bill of Rights]]

review_headline: Official Strategy Of Mandatory Poverty Through Eternal War
review_body:
The key part of the book is near the end where O'Brien is brainwashing Winston and explaining how the system works.

The Party's main problem is to keep the middle and lower classes hungry and fearful, and to make sure that the products of automation don't supply them with comfort and leisure.

The only way to do this is through eternal war, so that all excess production goes to weapons that are blown up or sunk in the ocean. It doesn't even matter if the war is real or not - the obsolete weapons are scrapped anyway. The important thing is to keep people poor so the class structure survives with the party on top.

The other key is to keep the population in a constant state of screaming enraged hatred. Anyone that looks \\"foreign\\" will get rounded up and executed. The country is saturated in phony \\"patriotism\\" over a war that probably doesn't even exist.

The government also pushes a national Puritanical drive to stamp out sex. And of course they use torture on a massive scale, and they apply it more or less randomly to get false confessions.

The only thing that make the book more anti-communist than anti-Fascist is that the Christian churches have been closed. The Nazis did not close churches, only synagogues.

Orwell was a life-long socialist but not a pacifist.

As I grow older, I recognize that my outlook on society and life as a whole has evolved. This change is not an immediate or an overnight change but rather a gradual shift that has occurred over months and years. These changes are the result of exposure to ideas.

1984 is a book that is frequently referenced these days, by terms like \\"Big Brother\\" or Orwellian. After reading an article stating that \\"1984 is upon us\\" I decided that it was time for me to read this book to fully understand why \\"1984\\" was significant in any way and applicable in the year 2013.

It only took me a little over 24 hours to read through this book. All depending on where you live in the world, you can download it for free because the copyrights have expired. If you live in the United States, you can certainly find an electronic copy online, however; to download it is illegal because the copyrights have not yet expired in the states.

The book is fairly easy to read, after the first few pages I found myself immediately captivated and drawn into the world that Orwell had imagined could be the future. I do not wish to spoil anything for you or plant any ideas in your mind about the value of this text, other than to say I expect it will change you.

I highly recommend reading this.

I've read this classic more than a dozen times over the years - a true literary masterpiece. If you appreciate 1984, try 2084 and \\"Two Wolves\\" by Hugh Darby.
http://www.amazon.com/Two-Wolves-Mr-Hugh-Darby/dp/1478133422/ref=sr_1_6?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1341952344&sr=1-6&keywords=hugh+darby
If you are wondering where we will be in 10 or 20 years if everyone sits fat and happy, well here ya go.

review_headline: read it, but it, share it
review_body: Must read, especially in America's recent political climate.  I cannot recomend this book enough.  Glad to see it in an super affordable paperback edition.

review_headline: Deviates corrected for their own good
review_body:
In a society that has eliminated many imbalances, surplus goods, and even class struggle, there are bound to be deviates; Winston Smith is one of those. He starts out, due to his inability to doublethink, with thoughtcrime. This is in a society that believes a thought is as real as the deed. Eventually he graduates through a series of misdemeanors to illicit sex and even plans to overthrow the very government that took him in as an orphan.

If he gets caught, he will be sent to the \\"Ministry of Love\\" where they have a record of 100% cures for this sort of insanity. They will even forgive his past indiscretions.

Be sure to watch the three different movies made from this book:
1984 (1954) Peter Cushing is Winston Smith
1984 (1956) Edmond O'Brien is Winston Smith
Nineteen Eighty-Four (1984) John Hurt is Winston Smith

In some way, many nation states would like to do this? Who will be the first one? Are we ready to live George Orwell fantasy?
Strong, visionary, and very crazy.
I really enjoy to read it once and once again.
Even written in 1954 becomes more pertinent every day! I have loved the work of Orwell from when I was a teenager in 1984 and his concerns and fears are as real today as ever.

Eric Blair (George Orwell) lived from 1903 to 1950. The novel 1984 was published in 1949.

Plot Kernel - Oceania, a socialist State, maintains its power by (1) the absolute control of public information, both of past history and of present fact, (2) control of the propriety, range and meaning of language and thereby of public speech and often of thought, (3) keeping itself at war, for the benefit of the attendant costs, (4) nearly inescapable surveillance of everyone in society, other than those of the lowest and uneducated class, which it deems of no threat to its power, (5) sadistic reprisals for disobedience to the State, either in act, intent, or revealed thought. Within Oceania, in the city of London, a man rebels, first in thought, then through intent, then in act. The State responds.

Comment - The surveillance society of Oceania is what 1984 is best known for: \\"Big Brother is Watching You\\" is what the posters in the novel say. They seem to imply an intentional threat against disobedience and disloyalty to the State. In the world of 2013, they would say \\"Big Brother Loves You\\" or \\"Don't Worry. Big Brother is Watching Out for You.\\" Now, the surveillance society is promoted as being motivated by concerns for public safety. Yet, a State seizes power through the abolition of privacy. The ultimate police state is one in which it is impossible to commit a crime without an immediate record of your actions and identity. In such a State, public safety is paramount; privacy is extinct. Don't be afraid. You are safe. Big Brother is watching.

review_headline: Not same cover as in picture
review_body: This book can be found in any paperback store or thrift shop. You can also probably just borrow a copy from the library or your grandmother's house. I only ordered this copy of 1984 because I wanted the awesome looking cover it has so it could be a part of my home library and I could show it off. The copy I received was a different super cheesy cover that didn't look good at all. Don't recommend.
My son had to read this for his Junior year High School English class. He said it was better than he had anticipated, but wasn't thrilled with it.

review_headline: An intelligent novel that has had an enormous influence
review_body: Several people who know me well were rather astonished that I had, in fact, never read 1984 by George Orwell. Considering both its status among the pantheons of literature as an important piece of art, and my penchant for smart science fiction that strives to have some social commentary or cultural relevance, it seemed obvious that I would've devoured it a couple decades ago. And now I wish I had read it long ago because it's a shame that it wasn't in my life until now. Just about every future-set totalitarian type regime ever conceived in any movie, TV show, or novel has Orwell's 1984 to thank. This is a beautifully tragic novel that, over half a century after it was published, is still full of concepts and ideas that feel uniquely fresh.

review_headline: Depressing yet a very essential read!
review_body:
1984 by George Orwell is a classic literature that depicts a world where the government is constantly in control of people's lives and are in constant monitor for any traitorous thoughts and actions. This is a very depressing book and I might even add that if your personal life is not going that great at the moment, please refrain from reading this book altogether! That is not a joke. 1984 is as dark as it can get and I have personally never read anything quite like it. However, I promise you that this book will get you thinking a lot not only about our present times but also what could happen in the far away future. This gem of a story is truly frightening in a way that I have never felt before either for a book read or movie watched. If you are tired of the usual horror flicks that employ the same scare tactics over and over again in hopes of making you jump out of your seat, then I dare you to read 1984 to experience a different kind of horror that affects a deeper part of your mind! I promise you that 1984 will leave a big impression in your lives well after you having finished with it.

In 1984, we step into the shoes of Winston Smith. Winston is like any other person living in a country where the Party is constantly watching your every move through telescreens and microphones. To survive in this new era, total submission to the Party's ways is an absolute must. Think and act any differently and you'll find yourself vaporized without any hint at all that you actually did existed. The problem with George is that his memory keeps him from being a total submissive person in this totalitarian government. As a reader, you're bound to have questions such as how did this government come to be? Were things always this way? Is life better now than it was decades ago? Well, please step inside the mind of Winston where even thinking of these questions are bound to get you vaporized if you aren't careful in controlling your emotions. If you've heard of the phrase that Big Brother is Watching You! at some point or another pointing to conspiracies about the government monitoring your every move be it cell phone conversations or Internet access, then be glad that you picked up 1984 because that is where the idea most likely originated from!

1984 starts off very slow and the author repeats many things throughout but once you start hitting that halfway point, get ready for a literal mind takeover from the author. I kept saying earlier that this book is horrifying in a special kind of way and if you actually picture yourself in Winston's position and picture in your head the things that he sees and witnesses, I'm sure you'll be scared as well. Better yet, picture your own self in Winston's place. Imagine having to live in a government similar to that of 1984. The beauty of portraying Winston to the readers is that we can all relate to him in one way or another. We like to sometimes think to ourselves that we are somehow \\"special\\". In 1984 however, you're no different than anyone else because the government tells you so. At first, you'll likely have a lot of questions and wonder how other humans cope with the whole situation. This is where things get interesting as you learn about the Party and its purpose.

It's definitely fascinating to learn that George Orwell published 1984 in 1949. Mr. Orwell is definitely who you would consider \\"ahead of his time\\" and 1984 proves that. For his story to still have some impact in today's society is amazing, especially to conspiracists. Can we win against such a government as that depicted here in 1984? What will it take to bring it down? Is it a lost cause? There will be so many questions you will ask yourself after the completion of 1984. That's a good thing however because 1984 is not meant to be just read once and completely forgotten the next day. This is truly a magnificent piece of work. Just be prepared to have every ounce of positive energy drained from you!e that Big Brother is Watching You! at some point or another pointing to conspiracies about the government monitoring your every move be it cell phone conversations or Internet access, then be glad that you picked up 1984 because that is where the idea most likely originated from!

1984 starts off very slow and the author repeats many things throughout but once you start hitting that halfway point, get ready for a literal mind takeover from the author. I kept saying earlier that this book is horrifying in a special kind of way and if you actually picture yourself in Winston's position and picture in your head the things that he sees and witnesses, I'm sure you'll be scared as well. Better yet, picture your own self in Winston's place. Imagine having to live in a government similar to that of 1984. The beauty of portraying Winston to the readers is that we can all relate to him in one way or another. We like to sometimes think to ourselves that we are somehow \\"special\\". In 1984 however, you're no different than anyone else because the government tells you so. At first, you'll likely have a lot of questions and wonder how other humans cope with the whole situation. This is where things get interesting as you learn about the Party and its purpose.

It's definitely fascinating to learn that George Orwell published 1984 in 1949. Mr. Orwell is definitely who you would consider \\"ahead of his time\\" and 1984 proves that. For his story to still have some impact in today's society is amazing, especially to conspiracists. Can we win against such a government as that depicted here in 1984? What will it take to bring it down? Is it a lost cause? There will be so many questions you will ask yourself after the completion of 1984. That's a good thing however because 1984 is not meant to be just read once and completely forgotten the next day. This is truly a magnificent piece of work. Just be prepared to have every ounce of positive energy drained from you!

I have always heard of this book and the way it has influenced many teachers and professors for mandatory reading,
probably in hopes that we can avert such time in our own lives, It is a good read especially if you are concerned of the way our country is heading.
Of course you know this. I bought this particular paperback for my high school student's English class assignment. Sometimes it matters that the kids all have the same edition.

review_headline: A brief explanation for my thoughts on 1984 and why I think the mainstream media created the Orwellian State
review_body:
The idea behind the 1984 movies and book was to condition people that the world is mad.
The way to do that lied in conditioning them to accept the situation expressed in this book - that of systematic control where merger states create trade unions and where the trade unions are used to opress the workers by means of constant monitoring. No one has access to privacy in any shape or form.
After September 11th, created by the mainstream media through the use of fake actors, it got easier for the mainstream media to convince people that the world is much less safe than it is, and therefore not the U.S. Federal Government.
Both Orwell and Huxley are believed to have been Fabian Society members and the story goes that is where they got their ideas from. The Orwellian State, as it is called, is thus overwhelmingly a mainstream media creation. That is why you'll see video cameras embedded on most stores and companies that have got access to the mainstream media or know people who have. Yet you're conditioned to believe that the people who orchestrated 1984, the Orwellian State and 9 - 11 are Federal Government Officials, when it appears to me to be the case, they're fake actors posing as feds. The idea was to condition people to believe that they were not powerful enough to resist against this. But as vast numbers of people kept resisting, the more the curtains behind what they called the NWO in the old days, kept collapsing and have since continued to collapse. The Surveillance State, or the Orwellian State, is there, and the people who are responsible for it's creation, got forced to confront the reality that, if they want to go to a war on terror, all they've got to confront to find the terrorists, is a mirror. In light of this, it is not surprising that people are becoming increasingly convinced that the Republic and Democrat Parties and the Tea Party might face overwhelming collapse in the near future. People want a different reality, and different world to experience and I agree with them. They have got every right to stop having to relieve 1984 every day. After all it was supposed to be a novel, not an instructions manual.d to experience and I agree with them. They have got every right to stop having to relieve 1984 every day. After all it was supposed to be a novel, not an instructions manual.

Simply put, everyone should read this book, It is beyond relevant for our times. I really wish this was compulsory reading for every student in high school. I often reference this book in every day conversation regarding the news - just like something out of 1984.
Volume was a bit low for listening in the car and they could have found a better reader - just not the right voice for books on tape.

I read this book when I was in high school a few years back and it's had a big affect on the way that I see the world ever since. As a western literary canon \\"1984\\" has had a huge impact on western culture even adding terms like Big Brother of double think to our lexicon. It gave me some insight on what happens/ could happen in a nation where the citizens are denied, or willingly give up, liberty for the greater good.  It's set in a future fascist dystopia where society is ruled by The Party headed by an enigmatic figure referred to as Big Brother. The people of this world are all either brainwashed and blindly accept everything that they are told or they are ruled by fear and go to great lengths to avoid punishment. Realizing this theme made me question if the world that I live in was not so different. It was the first George Orwell book that I'd read but afterwards I started to look into some of his other works, also classic novels, which all employed similar themes and helped give me some perspective on the world.
A really quality book, an overall good read I recommend it to everyone.  Book's physical quality was good as well, no big deficiencies.

review_headline: One of the Great Works of the Twentieth Century
review_body:
I have read \\"1984\\" several times in my life. However, it is probably thirty years since I last read it and that is way too long between drinks.

In my mind, George Orwell was a genius. It is a great tragedy that he died before his 47th birthday from tuberculosis. His was definitely a life cut short.

\\"1984\\" was Orwell's final book. The title meant no specific reference to how the world would be in the year 1984. Indeed, 1984 was probably simply a play on 1948 when the book was written. Rather, 1984 is a reminder of the dangers of totalitarianism. Orwell, no doubt, had the Soviet Union in mind when writing the book. An analogy today would be North Korea. Could the opening line of \\"It was a bright cold day in April, and the clocks were striking thirteen\\" be any more surreal? Does North Korea, for example, come to mind with this line?

\\"1984\\" covers a brief period in the life of Winston Smith who is employed in the Ministry of Truth to tell lies. That is the role of the ministry. The Ministry of Peace makes war, the Ministry of Love maintains law and order while the Ministry of Plenty manages scarcity. The world is dystopian. Misery and want abound. Happiness is never present. As Orwell wrote: \\"If you want a picture of the future, imagine a boot stamping on a human face - for ever.\\"

Since its publication in 1949, Orwell's magnum opus continues to resonate. \\"1984\\" is a book for the ages. If you have never read this work, you are poorer as a result. This is a book that should be on everyone's book shelf.
i purchased this for a long car drive and it's so long of a book that we had to continue listening to it on your way home but non the less hey it 1984 you can't beat that

review_headline: The most important book ever written?
review_body:
1984 by George Orwell is perhaps the most important book ever written.

The world has not been the same since it was written over 60 years ago. 1984 is a riveting, prophetical, disturbing, dystopian, haunting, terrifying, and profoundly important look at freedom, liberty, totalitarianism, government, knowledge, entertainment, technology, humanity, and Big Brother.

You need to read it. It might change your life, and will certainly open your eyes. It is both one of the most important and relevant books written in the 20th Century, as well as one of the most incredible books ever written.

Strongest recommendation!

review_headline: It's Orwell, of course it gets five stars!
review_body:
This should be required reading for every American. Unfortunately, it never will be because it reveals so much about our society. I stopped watching TV when I first read this novel in my pre-teens, and now, over a decade later, I have never gone back to that awful box. If you have not read 1984, read it, and have your kids read it, as well. Orwell was so right about the future that it's almost creepy.

Emancipate yourself from mental slavery, and read 1984!

No humor in this parody

The book asks a fundamental question: Can an individual survive in the face of the power of a collectivist State? Orwell was an egalitarian socialist who believed there was room for individualism, while warning about the Stalinist form of socialism. He hated central planning and oligarchical privilege. He recognized that collectivism compounds bondage and government power. He found hope in the proletariat, rather than the bourgeoisie..

Unlike the allegorical 'Animal Farm' there is no humor in this very serious parody of what the author saw in English centered world politics in 1948. He saw atomic weapons, developments in the USSR and UK socialism spreading to America. He saw continued rationing after war's end as government control of living standards. Today it's controlled inflation that serves the same purpose.

Orwell hated suppression of individualism, central planning and the collective oligarchy of either business or politics. His protagonist, Winston Smith, named after Churchill, has doubts and pangs of conscience and memory as he struggles to retrieve aspects of individualism and love in the dystopian world order of rule of the Party. It's an unusual character analysis as Winston's changes in outlook are not willful, being motivated by his subconscious or by coercion. Doubts intrude into Winston's suppressed memory in the forms of a surviving dairy of past memories and a photograph of a past forgotten event. His dreams and his bathroom are the only agendas immune from Party scrutiny. In the 1984 world order all capitalists (bourgeoisie) are gone. Their place as the middle class has been taken by Winston's small class of outer party functionaries.

As a psychologist and linguist, Orwell cleverly incorporates concepts of double think and Newspeak into the novel. History can be changed. Reality is what the Party says it is.
Today we can substitute Amsoc for Ingsoc. It's likely that one partyrule is here to stay. England went socialist in 1945. The USA followed 20 years later. Minor reversions in each local appear to have failed. World divisions are tending toward Orwell's concept of 3 groupings with parts of Africa as a no-man's land. So far the groupings are economic more than political. George Washington preceded Orwell in predicting a 'United States of Europe.'
The current world order is very similar to Orwell's idea in spite of the Soviet breakup.
Instead of war being used as a means of holding down living standards, our present government uses economic means including fiscal and tax policy with currency degradation and controlled inflation to maintain a death grip on our economy. Did Orwell hope that we would heed his warning? The possibility is growing more and more remote.

Today we see Orwellian doublethink in the “balanced” approach to debt reduction, in “bipartisanship” and especially in the claim of a “centralist” political position. Other examples of doublethink abound. Social security is savings. Control is regulation. Pork is infrastructure.
Education is investment. Credit and debt as money is an especially virulent doublethink.
We have triplethink (global warming will lead to another ice age, taxation of health care benefits is a choice) and circlethink (we owe it to ourselves).

Individual memory is suspect as psychologists and lawyers lose no opportunity to tell us.
Hate is necessary to focus popular opinion in the proper directions. Oceanans hate Eurasia, or Eastasia, and the long gone Emanuel Goldstein, capitalists and kings. The heavy note of pessimism predicts the inevitable triumph of the collective oligarchy. Individual freedom is doomed. Only doublethink saves individual freedom. History has been changed. The federalism of our founders has morphed into love of big government. Our Bill of Rights is now a mandate for federal protection. Thoughtless politically motivated hate is rampant. Today we hate the rich, obese kids, imagined monopolists, tea party obstructionists, the electoral college, British Petroleum and warming deniers. We hate Iran, deflation, hedge funds, short sellers, and even Wall Street, that symbol of wicked capitalism.

To qualify as literature the work is chock full of symbolism culminating in the smashing of the coral paperweight signifying final loss of hope. Nursery rhymes in song predict betrayal so that Winston and his love Julia eventually betray each other under State sponsored therapy administered at the Ministry of Truth. Big Brother parodies Stalin and Emanuel Goldstein parodies Trotsky, dead since 1940, but still an object of hate in 1948. The Golden Country of Winston's dreams signifies sexual freedom and freedom from observation. Chocolates signify a survival instinct in Winston's past with luxury for party members only. Rats involve psychology in place of torture. Music is used for control of the prole's emotions, as a war economy is used to suppress living standards. A single strong looking woman symbolizes Orwell's hopes for a proletarian future.

This is the world's last intelligent socialist writing about the world's last individualist. (Harry Hopkins died in 1946.) It's all very familiar and very real with regulation by the ministries of Truth, Love, Peace and Plenty, although we have many more today. There is great derogation of individualism in favor of collectivist patriotism. We see Party perks from retirement pensions and health care to free checking accounts. Pushing out of the middle class is accelerating along with animus against capitalists. Government has been substituted for country making for doublethink in the difficulty of loving one's country while hating our government. What formerly was patriotism is fast becoming the new way of saying “I Love Big Brother.”

Animal Farm by George Orwell

Like '1984', 'Animal Farm' depicts the perversions of a centralized economy. Orwell was that rare socialist who sees things the way they are. I see Orwell along with Harry Hopkins as the last smart socialists (read communists). Allegorical details of the book have been well depicted elsewhere so that the interesting exercise is to draw parallels to apply Orwell's lessons to present day politics. I find the book more like 'Wizard of Oz' than any other allegory although 'Gulliver's Travels' could serve as a model. Old Major could represent W.J. Bryon, whose financial ideals, a failure in their day, we hold firmly in thrall or J.M. Keynes whose economic ideals liberals pretend to follow. This extremely clever beautifully written political allegorical is called a fairy story rather than a fable because it lacks as pithy a moral as those provided by Aesop.

The details show impressive familiarity with Soviet history. There's every historical event from the Kronstat revolt to Stalin's purges to foreign agreements on trade and war. There are the Windmill attempts to rebuild the soviet economy with 5 year plans. Despite the extensive history lesson a lot is missing, including the Russo-Japanese War, the revolutions of 1905 and February 1917, Kerensky and the Provisional Government, Menshevik opposition, the murder of royal family at Ekaterinburg, extensive forced land redistribution, the Spanish civil war and the Hitler pact. We can only speculate on whether the omissions would have made for too complex a fairy story or whether Orwell had a deeper motive. 'A People's Tragedy' Orlando Figes's great history of the Russian Revolution takes over 800 pages and that one runs only to the death of Lenin in 1924.

Perhaps unintentionally, 'Animal Farm' illustrates other problems with socialism, lack of initiative and motivation, mentality of dependency, a modern version entitlement mentality. Today there is dependency on government for planning everything from environment to meals. It's clear that the barbs are directed at socialists, particularly in Russia, not socialism in general. The polemics of egalitarian central planning has now become synonymous with socialism. It's not clear whether Orwell recognizes that central planning is indistinguishable from totalitarianism. Although AF was written too early for Orwell to have seen failures in Russia, India, South America, Cuba, Africa and most of all the USA, Orwell was well aware that the Nazi rise to power was a reaction to the failure of Weimar socialism in Germany.

The black raven, Moses, emblematic of religion and bureaucracy, does no useful work as the pigs take all the economic surplus. While I'm familiar with the now stale metaphor of 'opium of the masses,' it's the first time I've seen it described in the sense of government coercion. Shades of the 'under God' clause in the 'Pledge of Allegiance.'

Besides his talent for allegory and political analysis, a major attribute of 'Animal Farm' is Orwell's precise use of language. It's difficult to analyze because the main charm is in what Orwell doesn't write. He eschews use of idiom, jargon or metaphors. He's entirely original. For example an amateur reviewer like myself might be tempted to say (pun intended) that the pigs lived high off the hog. Although such cutesy language appears to be very popular in modern best sellers. if that had been Orwell's style he would be long forgotten. Today's newspaper contains the inane simile “literally a ticking time bomb.” I have Orwell to thank for sensitivity to this style of vague popularism. Read his fine essay 'Politics and the English Language.' Ironically, Orwellian terms like “big brother” have found their way into the English language. He wouldn't use his own idioms.

Since the allegory and fable has been extensively reviewed in the last 65 years, I'll content myself with a bit of speculation on what Orwell might have thought about current US socialism. 'Animal Farm' depicts a gullible public believing political media generated spin war and peace even to denial when proven false. The distortions still resonate. Pravda spinner Squealer is typified by political mouthpieces. I'll refrain from naming them. Orwell allocates equal blame to Whymper for buying and Napoleon for selling. Our media blames corporations for buying influence attaching no responsibility to the government bureaucracy for influence being for sale. Deception of the populace and scapegoating is developed with the purported goal of equality, albeit without totalitarianism. The book ends with pigs indistinguishable from repressive humans.

Even though violent totalitarianism is lacking, the reader can draw many parallels to today's government. Much of the value of reading Orwell lies in reader's ability to draw parallels with the present time. After all part of his purpose was to warn that it could happen here. Orwell would certainly approve of President Obama, who implements socialism without violence in contravention to Lenin who said it couldn't be done. I've taken the liberty of drawing a few parallels between 'Animal Farm' and our present administration. The last item can be greatly extended.

review_body:

Now I read this book again, and the plot is very - frightening - close to reality. Many of the mind-washing methods are in use today, like campaing promisses and even presidential speeches about "soaring economy", "record-breaking production", and even "the sacrifice in our well-beign for a brighter future"...
Note: 50 years ago, there was no Internet. Just picture what George Orwell could have written then about our present...

review_headline: A must read for our time
review_body:
“1984” by George Orwell is a dark prophetic look at the life of Winston Smith, the protagonist of the story, who lives under the rule of Big Brother who is the figurehead of the Party, the evil totalitarian government of Oceana. The story is told from Winston’s perspective as he falls in love with Julia, which is forbidden as all devotion must be reserved to the Party. He also has an unusually warm relationship with an Inner Party member by the name of O’Brien who turns out to be Winston’s ultimate antagonist as he represents the Party in his every action. The reason that this book is such a timely piece of literature for today is that the world around us is going through dramatic changes in its structure. None of us could know where this cycle will lead, but Orwell provides us with a nightmare of where the tide of history and government could come to rest and how an average man may live and feel under such conditions.
While this does not naturally appear as a love story, it does actually take an important look at a dark side of love and devotion. The Party demands more than absolute obedience; it demands the love of every subject. Even to the degree that no other love interest can be maintained. It is a very religious theme, similar to what you might hear during a Sunday morning sermon or straight from the Bible, “Anyone who loves his father or mother more than Me [Jesus] is not worthy of Me” (Matthew 10:37, New International Version). Winston’s love for Julia is ultimately the reason that Winston is tortured mercilessly and his love for her is what is used to finally break his will at the climax of his incarceration in the Ministry of Love.
Winston also maintains a curious relationship with the stories antagonist, O’Brien, throughout the story. Early in the story, the two of them share a glance which indicates to Winston that they have similar interests regarding the overthrow of the current system. As it turns out, O’Brien has been working throughout the book to entrap him and presumably anyone else who might be caught up in ideas of overthrow. He is ultimately Winston’s interrogator, torturer and re-educator. However, even as he is being horribly tortured, Winston continues to hold a very high regard for O’Brien as he notes, “The peculiar reverence for O’Brien, which nothing seemed able to destroy, flooded Winston’s hear again” (Orwell, 1949, p. 225). Winston would go on to betray Julia, but would never lose his admiration for O’Brien.
Orwell’s story takes the idea of “big government” to its most extreme conclusion. The story is particularly timely in a day when our own nation has clearly voted in recent months for a larger, more intrusive federal government. America has shifted over the years from larger to smaller, less regulated government and back again throughout our history. However, it is interesting that Orwell gives an idea of how one party was able to stop the pendulum from swinging by ensuring that average people were stopped from obtaining wealth. Orwell (1949) uses the following passage to describe the process used to obtain total control of the society: “It was possible, no doubt, to imagine a society in which wealth in the sense of personal possessions and luxuries, should be evenly distributed, while power remained in the hands of a small privileged caste…In the long run, a hierarchal society was only possible on a basis of poverty and ignorance” (p. 156).
In the end, Winston is a beaten man who has failed to stand up to the power of Big Brother in any way. His character represents the limitations of the individual against an all powerful government. His mind is coerced and his love confused. The Party has done with him as it has with all others and will continue to do. And the story concludes with no hope for a positive resolution. This is a story which should be read by everyone to ensure an understanding of the evil capable of a powerful government.

REFERENCE:

Orwell, G. (1949) 1984 New York, NY: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, Inc.

review_headline: No longer Science Fiction nor Fiction for that matter
review_body:
This is a powerful book that I first read in high-school and like with most everything in school you don't fully appreciate until you are much much older. With that in mind I recently re-read this classic and was shocked and appalled how much of George Orwells dark and dreary vision has become a reality in our lives since my high school days.

Winston the protagonist in this book is a low level party grunt working at the Ministry of Truth in a fictional London dedicated to scrub history books and records of inconvenient facts, such as who we are at war with and why to streamline history into lockstep with the ever changing party line. Orwell foresees technology that for his day was in its infancy and describes how this technology can be used to oppress people and that whoever controls the past will control the future (and present).

Orwell Imagines a world in which every home has a two way 'television', that is used inbound to disseminate propaganda while at the same time allowing the thought police to check up on its citizens. Virtually every inch of his imaginary world is covered in listening and spying devices and even small deviations from the norm carry the death penalty. Winston's crime is to keep a journal to record his own version of history, this will ultimately bring down the thought police on him, who (SPOILER) captures, tortures and kills him, but not before breaking his spirit and making him love big brother and his henchman.

The most striking thing about this book is that we can see almost all of Orwells more imaginative concepts come to life in our modern day society, not necessarily exactly the way the author envisioned them, but in a more subtle but no less disturbing way. One can't help to draw parallels between Orwells concept of thought crime and the political correctness movement that is doing its best - and succeeding in - making certain words unspeakable and by extension certain thoughts unthinkable. It's chilling to read a news article on how interest groups trying to change Mark Twains classic to strike a specific word from the book for school versions where it is appropriate in both the text as the context of the time it was written. The ministry of truth resides not as a specific location it rather resides with special interest groups fighting to revise history.

The Internet - obviously unimaginable at the time - serves as a close and even more powerful parallel to the ever present surveillance in Orwells world, but instead of a government forcing us to be available (and surveillable) we willingly surrender our deepest emotions, private thoughts and actions to social media sites like Facebook and twitter where they are for sale to the highest bidder including our government.

9/11 as global watershed moment has served as justification for more and more snooping and warrant less searches while our airports serve as testing ground on how much more privacy intrusion we are willing to take at one point. In the name of 'homeland security' we are living in fear of the boogie man, not Goldstein, but Osama Bin Laden and his band of Islamic terrorist serving as the external threat on which more and more intrusions on our personal freedoms are being justified with.

If you ever wonder how a prequel to 1984 would look or how Orwells world got to where it is, turn on your TV and browse the Internet and you will find that you are living it. It is not 5 minutes till noon, it may be 5 mi uses past noon and we haven't realized it yet...

Orwell vividly paints a horrific picture of this fictional futuristic society, which is all the more terrifying because of the similarities drawn with the present.

1984 is as real and frightening now as it was in 1948, 1984 or any other time period. The difference is it was mostly conceived as a political story originally but has now become terrifyingly accurate and real in a high-tech world of government and corporate surveillance. Privacy is a major concern now when in the 1980s it was hardly given any mention or great concern. 1984 is about a government worker (Winston) who enjoys his job but starts to have suspicions about what is really going on in the world. The government severely restricts individual freedom, religion, choice of partner (procreation is not particularly encouraged), choice at all, movement and occupation. Winston starts to slip up and slip into the dark side. He knows he will get caught but cannot help himself. Yet Winston dreams the proletariats will rise up to defeat Big Brother. Is there some force in us which cannot be defeated? It is a powerful work that everyone can relate to. George Orwell has been blatantly copied by scores of book and film writers for over 50 years. Read the original for yourself and be amazed. Is the idea of 24-hour a day surveillance, \\"hall passes\\", spying, control, restriction and propaganda that far off? All in the \\"good intentions\\" of protecting us.

Buy this book. 1984 has been in print a long time and has held its value remarkably well.
