review_headline: As far as R-rated content goes:
review_body:
Fantastic modernist novel. I enjoyed it thoroughly. As far as R rated content, there is some. However, the novel does not embellish or dwell on it more than what is necessary. One of the principles of the Society in which Winston lives in is that the natural desire for sex should be abolished, so the adultery is not portrayed in a negative light; in fact, it is portrayed as quite a positive part of the story. I personally did not agree with the way this was handled, but overall, the sketchy parts I would rate as 'not-as-bad-as-Brave-New-World' but 'probably-worse-than-The-Great-Gatsby.' (Of course I mean sexual content, not writing or plot.)
Hope this was helpful!
This is a great book! Well written and very interesting!

review_body: Excellent book and quite pertinent with regards to society in 2014, with all the information that is available on each of us, it is not difficult for society to manipulated in a similar fashion to 1984.

There have been times when I have read this book and could have sworn it was written by someone who time traveled forward and went back and wrote what he didn't understand. Most notably were the ear shells in his wife's ears as well as the TV wall. Looking at the sizes of televisions these as compared to when the book was written is especially interesting.
I understand his desire to just get away and not be watched all the time, and write about a time that he could hardly remember. It was written so long ago yet I can see so many similarities between it and our creeping police state. Every other year or so, I re-read it and Eli Weisel's Night. One man's experience in a different world. My Weiseal's was non fiction and he lived it but I have no doubt that one day soon we will remember that & 1984 and go searching for them, only to find that they are down the memory hole
George Orwell does a fantastic job linking a fictional book with profound thoughts, through the use of metaphors. This is a typical dystopian novel.

review_headline: I've read King, Poe, and Lovecraft, and this is the scariest book I've ever read.
review_body:
I believe '1984' is standard reading for many high school/college English classes, but it wasn't in mine. I decided to read it on my own this summer, and boy am I glad I did.

1984 tells the story of Winston Smith, a man who lives in THE totalitarian government, wants to fight back, and isn't entirely sure how. He is watched almost all the time, must be constantly on guard against showing dissent from the party, or else he will be disappeared. While he and similar characters aren't exactly brimming with personality, they don't need to be to make this book good.

The greatest thing about this book is the government itself. A common saying in this book is [paraphrased] 'he who controls the past controls the future, and he who controls the present controls the past'. Orwell goes into detail on how to accomplish this, and delivers on all of the horror, both stated and unstated, that goes along with it. The even more classic line 'War is Peace' is brought up, and explained in such a way that I even found it plausible in a severely twisted sort of way. And the worst part? All of this misery, terror, and oppresion? It's entirely believable that it could happen to us. The government doesn't need any sci-fi tech to take absolute control, and they don't need it. Heck, North Korea is doing something similar right now!

One minor thing I have to say I like is the prose. A lot the book I've read that are sixty years have a lot of archaic grammar and word choice. 1984 doesn't for the most part.

I recommend this book to anyone interested in classic literature, second only to 'Catch-22' in my list of books you should read. So, you know, buy it.

review_headline: Easy read, but not a happy story
review_body: This book made me really question my understanding of human nature, truth, and individual importance. The book took no wild turns, I knew just as Winston did that there would be no happy ending. Even so, I think it was important to read.
The world was robbed of an intellectual giant when Orwell died. This is a must read for any thinking person.

I think George Orwell was a prophet of fiction.  I like the thought police because I have seen evidence of this idea in current events.  I didn't like how Winston and Julia betrayed each other, but at the same time I did like it because it seems more real.
I didn't care for this book. It made me depressed.
Great book with an incite on the future. I enjoyed the movie as well. At times kind if boring but really good.
I liked the idea behind this book. Unfortunately it was.too mundane for my taste. I guess it's just not my style.

I had heard a lot about this book relating it to the times we live in now.  I can see a lot of parallels between this book and the media etc we have today.  People are no longer private thanks to the internet and much of the other public  material on a person.  Very thought provoking.

review_headline: I can't believe  it took me this long to read it
review_body: Well written. A must read for all. I should have read it in high school, but 25 years later I'm happy I finally read it.

review_headline: Today's government-controlled technology makes 1984 more interesting now.
review_body: When I was forced to read the book back in high school, the surreal environment didn't seem possible nor very interesting.  The dreary surroundings were simply dull and the circumstances of the characters I couldn't identify with.  However, at an age when I can better appreciate the entire book experience, I find the book to be infinitely more interesting than it was back then. In some ways, with the NSA snooping on cell phones and drones now a reality, intrusion by government into one's life is now not only possible but happening--and 1984 seems a little more plausible than it was 30 years ago. Perhaps it's not a Tom Clancy or Michal Creighton novel, but it has a more than adequate narrative to describe a world lacking hope and completely driven by selfishness and greed.

At times it was a very challenging read, but I managed to get through those parts. It is still timeless and relevant to the vast number
of changes that are occurring in our society today. Its still a scary book as it foretells our potential future.

review_headline: A marxist critique of a facist society
review_body:
This book has three parts to it, part one is pure exposition about the party, giving you perspective and the proper feeling that you are a part of oceania. Part two is where our main character dissent's from his government, realizing it's flaws and vowing to undermine it. Part three ill leave as a surprise, but it's a real mind bender that makes you question psychology, the limits of the human spirit, and what power really is.

When i recommend this book to my friends -- which i do often -- i always preface it by saying that it's Orwell's depiction of the potential totalitarian direction the world could have gone after the end of World War II. Since the book was written 1948, and i have yet to read his other books, i assume that this was either his way of foreshadowing the worst to come, or to put projected government post world war as extreme as possible. Whether that's true or not, it's an excellent read, a classic, and i'd say necessary for any collection
Such an interesting book from so long ago. It really makes you think while you're reading it and I just can't seem to put it down.
Such an eye opening book. I love it! It's crazy how similar 1984 is to the way the world is today.

Read this book in Jr. high or High School. Thought it was amazing then! Fast forward to the 21st Century & Orwell is Spot On with Big Brother & trying to play down or dumb down people's thoughts, lives & kill to keep it that way.

How Orwell knew what was going to happen to this country he must have seen it coming when he was alive! Unbelievably great work. Going to read Animal Farm another great book by George Orwell!

review_headline: 150% great for high school and above
review_body: Orwell couldn't have done better with this classic. Not only a good read for personal benefits, but this book is used in highschools and colleges around the world. A great read to discover dystopian literature as well.

This book certainly leads you to expect a certain plot outcome, through hundreds of pages dotted with tiny hints. However, only after you are fully convinced that you know what is going to happen, Orwell takes you expectation and thoroughly shreds it in front of you. He builds up your expectation for joy only to tear it down and punch you in the face. This book is unforgiving and thoroughly good.
A very interesting read about a bleak future with no privacy. One of the best books I've read. I just wish it was longer since I wanted more.

review_headline: Grab Your Weapons and Hide Your Families!
review_body:
Corruption! Corruption! Those dirty scoundrels! We must stop this slaughter! Big Brother must answer to his crimes! Join our cause if you wish to rid yourself of the shackles of oppression! Join us if you are
willing to fight for a noble cause: Equality! Tally ho and may God be with you!

I enjoyed this classic because it is as relevant in today's societies as when it was written.
Who is Big Brother today? Multi National Corporations, governments that do not represent the interests of their people or a media that is more cynical than critical
relates to what is going on now, but the book was not an easy read. too much about sex and not what I expected. I thought it would be alittle more exciting a longer.
It was good but I felt it took forever to get to the climax and the falling action was to short,
After reading this I feel I need to go through it again. I don't wish to spoil anything but this book left me with a profound sense of sadness. I hope this work of fiction never comes true.

This is an extreme interpretation of what can be possible in a future totalitarian state. Orwell dashes our hopes for Winston and Julia which leaves the reader with not a glimmer of hope. There are shades of Stalin's Russia. Hitler and Stalin would have loved to have had their own Thought Police
Not only is this novel brilliant in and of itself, but its pervasive influence to this day is a testament to the quality of the work and the ideas represented.
This is an exellent portrail of anti utopian society and of what the 2nd world war could have turned into

review_headline: Might be good in another time
review_body: If I had read this when it first came out, I might feel differently about the book.  Reading it today, I found the writing style very difficult to read and over all it is just too stupid sounding considering of what we know today about technology.  Couldn't finish it.
Interesting concept and I can see how this writing is compared to what is happening in our world today, but it was very non climactic and the character development was lacking.
A very complex book, that makes you think about alot of things when compared to life. I loved the plot and storyline, that is, until the end. I wish it would have been different in some way.

I thought I knew the story, but I was wrong in so many ways. I knew Big Brother was BIG, but I did not know he was doublebiggest, my contribution to Newspeak. It is incredible how this seemingly crazy guy, writing in the 40's, was so insightful about the world of 1984 as well as 2014. A good book deserves a happy ending. A great book has this kind of an uneasy, thought provoking finish.
George, I cannot wait for your new release.
Interesting, but so wordy and preachy. I read it just because it is on reading lists, so I wasn't disappointed.

review_headline: Still Not Crazy After All These Years
review_body:
A recent discussion motivated me to re-read "1984" after 40 years or so. It still works.

About totalitarianism, it's still a good account, but you can see the frayed edges in his tapestry. Not surprisingly, Orwell's fictional technology of surveillance does not match the real-world technology of modern times. And, typically of practically all futuristic literature, the economic plausibility of the depiction is lacking. (The number of people tracking the attitudes of Winston and Julia, and the time invested in that project, would quickly bankrupt any economy, no matter how finely tuned, were it applied to everyone in similar circumstances.)

But Orwell's relentless description of thought control is uncannily contemporary. The project to continually remake memories, to literally eradicate the past by constantly recreating history, looks terribly like our world of manipulable records. Michael Chrichton's "Rising Sun" (1992) worried about how digital photography could be modified to the point that the original was impossible to identify. More recently, a New Yorker magazine article by Michael Specter ("Partial Recall") told about clinical progress toward excising painful memories and replacing them with different, constructed memories. The aim is clinical, to repair mental trauma. But you ought to compare this new technology to the methods of the thought police in "1984." It's disconcerting, to say the least.

It isn't much of a stretch to read this book and the path America is going down. In fact, the entire world seems to be going down the path where Big Brother seems to rule every aspect of lives, whether it be the NSA snooping, no knock SWAT raids, false news from \\"the front“ in the war on terror, drone strikes, or so called \\"hate crime\\" laws. All the elements of an Orwellian society are in place-the Ministry of Peace (requires just the right force to not win the war, but keeps the country in a state of equipoise) is the Department of Defense, the Ministry of Love (enforces loyalty to Big Brother) is the Department of Justice, and the Ministry of Truth (dedicated to rewriting history) is the Department of Education. Everyone should read this book and heed its warnings of what happens when the state controls every aspect of our lives.

In the novel 1984 by George Orwell, a party member named Winston becomes conflicted by his society after questioning why? He quickly finds himself in a downward spiral. He’s disappointed when he notices that the Party alters the truth. As the story progresses, Winston meets a younger girl named Julia. Winston and Julia become close and develop an intimate relationship together. They discover that they both endure hate towards the Party and Big Brother. The comrades start to rebel against the Party and become members of the Brotherhood. Towards the end of the novel, Winston and Julia are arrested for thoughtcrime. They are brought to the Ministry of Truth. Winston is tortured and interrogated by O’Brien until he learns, accepts, and understands his love for the Party and Big Brother. After being reintegrated into society, Winston is brought back to the Ministry of Truth and is killed.
This novel isn’t a modern-day literature. It’s told at a time where there is technology but not our average computer and phone. There are telescreens and memory holes. The telescreens are used to watch over the people who live in Oceania. The memory holes are used to erase data that is no longer true. Oceania is a dictated state. The story is revealed through Winston who often writes in a diary. It’s not a thriller, romance, or adventure story. Instead, it’s a dystopian novel. It’s more like a grim view of the future with less technology. However, there’s a great deal of irony. Although, there isn’t a lot of humor or entertainment. 1984 is very challenging to read and can sometimes become tedious. Furthermore, 1984 isn’t a part of a series so don’t look for any upcoming releases for a new book.
Overall, I would recommend this novel to someone else. There are many different meanings to interpret which will keep you interested. This literature sheds light into the nature of inhumanity. The intense plot will keep you at the edge of your seat. Lastly, 1984 will make you think about how the world will be in the near future. Reading 1984 made me question if our world would gradually change into a world like Oceania. What if the Golden Country was a reflection of modern day today? Without a doubt, I enjoyed reading 1984 by George Orwell.
Thought provoking... Excellent. Orwell was way ahead of his time. What a mind! A must read for all. Can be disturbing
Finally read this book and thoroughly enjoyed it. Incredible vision George had. The book is darker than I expected for some reason,  but a great story.
A prophetic word retelling history and foretelling the future! We've studied the history and we're living the future... a bit scary!
Orwell was definitely ahead of his time with this story. Alot of what he stated in 1984 seemed to be drawn right from todays society and political arena. A must read.

review_headline: ok but for a classic ive read better
review_body: Seems light for an ending. Perhaps there should have been a sequel. Not an easy read. interesting book for what it is but most should pass on this classic.

review_headline: Fascinating.... Exciting the underlying philosophy of this book is still valid today in some cultures
review_body: Fascinating.... Exciting, the underlying philosophy of this book is still valid today in some cultures.......even in the free world. it's amazing how you can put yourself into a book pretending and thinking about a way of living.
Any person that thinks a large government is a good thing, should read this book, an excellent thought provoking read.
While many of the ideas in this book such as "Big Brother" have entered the language and some scary concepts like constant surveillance were predicted, the book drags on with excessive restatement.
Fantastic, thought provoking, disturbing and possible!  Applicable in this date and time with the current administration. I have recommended this to many.
The concepts presented in this book were laid out well but were extremely chillingly horrific for a horrible unwanted future.
This is a classic novel.  Not sure how I was never required to read this in all my schooling, but it is definitely one that should be read!

review_headline: Gotta read this a few more times
review_body: This is one of those books that are worth reading again and again. Each time I read it I get something new, I know it.

This book remains a stark warning against security-obsessed governments, power-loving leaders, and those who might enable both.  A balance exists between liberty and order, but 1984 is a fine place to start with what's wrong with order.
A prophetic account of our chilling future. A must read for all that see a conspiracy behind every bush. Could be a time we are walking into.

review_headline: A classic that is still relevant.
review_body: Seriously why haven't you read this book? This is still one of the most thought provoking books ever written. At times you will think that modern governments misunderstood it's purpose, that governments think it's an instruction manual and not a warning. Just read this book! It's fantastic!

The modern parallels I saw in the book were frightening, that being said the world and characters George Orwell created were very believable. I really enjoyed this book and it is one the people should read.

review_headline: striking political commentary, written way ahead of its time.
review_body:
"Every year, fewer and fewer words, and the range of consciousness always a little smaller."
-Winston
Even today, in a real world, this book rings true in many ways.

Absolutely excellent book.  I loved the development of Winston, a hero without heroic qualities.  Whatever your literary preference is, take time to read this as it will enhance your literary perspective.  This book is classic for a reason.

review_headline: This is more a manual than a warning.
review_body: Phenomenal book. Too bad it's not required reading before citizens are allowed to vote. I read this in high school and it was just "ok" at he time. Now that I've lived a little, it's worth every penny.

Great book to read a second time.
Winston comes acros as a willing participant
In the end I would read this book again.
Re-read this after many years and still a classic. A MUST read  in today's uncertain world of privacy and freedom.
A world of "what-if" the government had complete control of the past, future, and your thoughts. An interesting read if you like sci-fi.
What can I add to the already multitude of reviews, essays, assignments, and imitations of Eric Blair's dystopia? Better people than I have critiqued this book. I will leave it to them.

review_headline: Is this where we are heading?
review_body: Read the book because of hearing references of "Big Brother."  Interesting story line but gets a little deep in the middle of the book but finishes well.

review_headline: referenced so much in American politics you have to read it
review_body: But it really isn't in the upper echelon of books written. And I take issue with his \\"sex as freedom\\" theme that made no sense at all and occupied a third of the book.

This book was required reading at my high school.  More than Half of my lifetime ago.  I had ignored it then.  Skimmed it.  Forgotten it.  It never occurred to me then that Orwell was only off by about 30 years.

I liked this book, and as a 17 year old, I naturally have a slight distrust for authoritative figures. 1984 is a brilliant example of things that are happening now, with NSA surveillance and wire tapping within the government walls. The fact that it can easily be tied into today's society make it that much better.
Amazing for a book that was written in 1948.  Must read even if you have read it before.  Now I know where the word "Orwellian" comes from.
Worst ending ever! But, still a great book. Gives you a look at totally different world of a utopian society and makes you thankful that you are where you are right now.

I thought this an anxious read in the beginning and startling ending. I remember this being required reading in my high school back in the late '80s.  It's a historical read who's lesson should not be forgotten.

review_headline: Future or Past what really happened ?
review_body: I remember reading this in high school, back then it was about the future. And reading it now it's about the past.It was interesting to compare what the author George Orwell thought the future would be , and how the past really was . For instance there is no \\"Big Brother\\" watching your every move..

This book just... Left me speechless. What started out as an assignment fit school ended as a total consumption of this book.
Although it can be dry, I was blown away.
This was my first George Orwell book, it is very imaginative and as always way better than the movie :-).

This is a wonderful book that has me amazed at the humans mind.  Here is an example of a book written 40 years in the future,  and is now based 30 on a future that could have happened 30 years ago.  It's timeless.  Here is a book that obviously has a very perceptive grasp on human nature and how possible it is for our kind to create a world where we have  lost the battle of individual freedom.

Scariest nightmare one can have. A world without curiosity and enjoyment. Where 2+2 is 5, white always mated in a chess game and whatever Big Brother wished. Orwell created such an absurd world to say that Shakespeare is the solution. And it means that we got to fell madly in love by something to break stupid systems. By something, something! (Read it again with the Rocky Balboa’s emphatically voice).  :-)
1984 may have come and gone, but Orwell's depiction of the future is still chilling and his insight into human and inhuman nature is still relevant.

review_headline: good ideas but a little frustrating an d boring
review_body: The book has really good ideas but very slow, boring and depressing. A lot of details could have been removed.

Some of the imagery was intense in a suspenseful way where little hints of what was coming is expressed though symbols. The symbolism of some of the objects had an immense meaning beyond what they were, which I enjoyed greatly. I must say that Winston's journey was like conforming to what the ministry intended: everyone accepting and loving big brother. big brother was nothing more than an idea of "power" which was used to strike fear into everyone. An example of this fear was the thought police and paranoia of being caught because of the slightest imperfect thought. These thoughts were the opposite of what made sense but more of what they wanted to believe. The belief that everyone is malleable into an ideal citizen was what O Brien wanted to instill in Winston.

The book was amazing, there was lessons of , love, rebellious acts, betrayal, and beliefs. Each person is controlled by the things that they wanted, which is what ultimately led to certain
consequences.

haunting. captivating. thought provoking. terrifying. shocking. stimulating. tragic. vivid. creative. forceful. relevant. depressing. enlightening. bleak. complete. intimate. brave. timeless. punishing.

review_headline: Finally read it... an excellent, if not a bit unnerving, book.
review_body: Although the US does not have a "big brother" in the 1984 sense, the recent NSA scandals demonstrate that we're not that far away.

I had to read this book for my 10th grade pre-A.P English class. When I first learned we'd be reading this book I wasn't to excited.. the beginning was interesting, but some parts in the middle were to dull for my liking. BUT the ending was amazing. Overall  I loved the book, but I wouldn't recommend it because if I hadn't been forced to read it for my English class I wouldn't have given this book a second thought let alone a glance.

I really enjoyed the storyline.  The plot moved very well.  I was always cheering for Winston.  The end was not what I was expecting.  My only problem with the story was the lengthy description of Goldstein's book.  Overall it was very well done.

review_headline: Allllllmost lived up to the hype
review_body: Wonderfully structured and presented. Orwell was great at organizing both inner thoughts and dialogue in a non-confusing way. The reputation preceded itself, and took away from the emotional reaction I was hoping to get

review_headline: Classic...scary, disturbing and suprisingly relevant- even today.
review_body: Never read this book in high school so I decided to check this out- probably the original dystopian novel with what is a relevant theme especially today...the overarching political ideology is brutal and terrifying, even if a bit far-fetched in how much power the "party" wields over the populace with the dominating, all-seeing and supposedly omnipotent leader "big brother" maintaining perfect social order-which is what I found the most frightening. Still though, could not put it down. Should definitely be a mandatory read in secondary schools today, not sure why we didn't read this in my day!
Reading 1984 was quite the journey. Although the ending was not what I hoped for or expected I still liked the book.
Curious ideas which make you think of what you would do in the situation... Makes you wonder how much free think & doublethink we have going on (Let the conspiracy theories run rampant!)
Fantastic read. Thoroughly enjoyed from start to finish! I couldn't put the book down and I am looking forward to some more orwell novels
Really good book, had to read it for school, but it was really interesting. It gripped me in within the first few chapters.
Sometimes it's a big slow, but overall very good read.  Interesting and a little scary.  Good for a book club because I definitely would have liked to discuss the ending with others

review_headline: I like the book, just not this Kindle edition
review_body: Once I read the introduction, and tapped the screen to advance to chapter 1, etc ... it jumped to 40% done, and I had to go back.  I tried this twice, to make sure there wasn't some problem with my Kindle .. no.  This implementation of the book has an error, at least this one.

It was just as I expected reading a book about the pasts future. There are some rough patches you'll have to trudge through but I think it is a must read for high schoolers to tie into philosophy and English classes.
Orwell captures the essence of perfect subjugation in a dystopian setting. Written with master precision with jewels of wisdom on almost every page. Truly a classic.

I would recommend this book to anyone who enjoys reading books written 50+ years ago that somehow end up having an eerily prophetic foresight into the society in which we currently live. Novels such as 1984 warn the readers how quickly a society could go from it's current state to one as described in this book. Loved it.
Pretty good. I get bored with the long philosophical reading. Otherwise a great book. Well written, I love the characters

review_headline: Good read... interesting how current the story seems
review_body: This book speaks to how power corrupts.  absolutely.  started a little slow but definitely picked up and ended too quickly.

I picked this up because it is considered a cautionary warning that folks should read. The message it sends may become more relevant as technology continues to expand and improve and government is able to reach deeper into our lives with monitoring technology. I doubt that society will ever reach this depth of surrender but it seemed like something one should read any way. It was depressing, confusing, and a little frightening.

At 1st I considered the book a bit slow going but that was for a reason as I found out later.  The writing was great and very detailed.  It was hard to put this book down and as the time went by I was wanting so bad to finally get to the end.  I find the things he said to be partial truth at this time in the world.  For all we know it could be worse than we think, that's the point, what do we really know? The ending broke me.  But for someone back in 1948 writing about the world generations ahead of his time he hits it hard and drives the nails into our coffins.  Should you read this, which I would recommend, it would be best if you knew a lot about what is really going on in the world and I'm not talking about watching main stream media.

I haven't even finished this book and already want to drown myself in horse semen. I can't even imagine that the author of this book was too much of a pussy to even keep his real name. I knew immediately that this book would suck because it was recommended to me by my English teacher. I now know how bad womens' taste in literature is and will not be voting for Hillary Clinton anytime soon.
Book everyone should read. Depressing, yet thought provoking as well. If you didn't read it when you are supposed to like myself, you'll enjoy later in life.

I first read 1984 in 1974, when I was a teen.

Reading it again, 40 years later, left me darkly disturbed. In addition to the dystopia everybody is familiar with, this piece tackles some elemental aspects of what it means to be human.

And of course the dystopia is far more real now than 1974, meaning this book needs to be read by everybody now.
That was horrifyingly interesting and I recommend it. All stars for the quality and story. George Orwell did a scarily good job

review_headline: technology in the hands of political power
review_body: this, of course, was required reading 40 years ago. today it is even more disheartening. How will we preserve humanized institutions?
This was quite an amazing book. I found myself entranced by the writing style and use of imagery. But I was very dissapoitned
Great book, it was easy to read and well written. I found the plot interesting and didn't predict the end at all.
Oligarchy, totalitarianism, power, betrayal, hatred. The thought police, what does 2 and 2 make? Winston Smith, the Party, does all hope lay with the proles?
I think that this book is ok. I Had to read it as a class assignment. It an get a little confusing.

The rendition of Newspeak and forgetfulness of the evolution of logic are a novel behind Orwell. that this work portends to predict our direction beyond  the leanings  of the twentieth century have certainly been verified.now at the beginning of the twenty-first century.. The use of gerrymandering to expand illogic can lead to debasement of our world as well as our nation. I can only wish that there is  turnaround and this nation ad world becomes better.

A very heavy and relevant piece even today. However, be forewarned. Much of the sensual imagery is revolting and should be skipped over; you won't miss much. This should not be taken as a novel, with a conflict and resolution. Rather it is a study of the truth of what is fact and what is merely contained within our skulls.

Honestly speaking it's a very very very good book, I really love it's atmosphere and how George Orwell introduces us to this totalitarian world of Oceania.

5/5 I recommend reading this to everyone. You won't regret wasting your time on it believe me!
This is one of the all time best books I have ever read. I have read 1984 several times over the years and it still is an interesting story. I think this should be read by every one at some point.
The orwellian society is one of the best reads for understanding how fragile the human condition is and how to protect yourself from losing humanity

review_headline: Big Brother is really watching you!
review_body:
Great story, if not completely depressing. It's amazing as to how close this is to today's reality.
A recommended read to see the parallels with our government of today.
Just because you don't think you are important enough for them to be watching your every move, doesn't mean they aren't.
I found this to be very strange in the beginning and then it got interesting. Found myself skimming to get to the point... not sure I found it. I was dissappointed at the ending.
Read this as things between Russia and Ukraine flared up. Putin had his wife's name expunged from his biography. Vaporized almost. Blair hits the nail on the head over and over again. Excellent.

review_headline: I reference this at least once a week
review_body: Prophetic, insightful, hardly a fantasy, still so relevant. Although the world is NOTHING like it was when he wrote this in terms of technological advancement, this book is strong evidence that the more things change, the more they stay the same...

A perfectly crafted novel. It seems to me to be the model for all horror written after 1948, but with a political point. Dystopian perfection. I could have done without the extensive quoting of The Book, but otherwise perfect. This Kindle edition was completely adequate; no problems that I can remember.

1984 was my book club read for this month. It seems everyone else had read it before and it was interesting hearing their take on the book from when they were 16 and what they thought of it now. It has been on my to read list for a while, but I hadn't read it in school or anything. It was an interesting read, but the writing didn't engage me that much. I didn't feel for the characters like I should have. Not quite sure why.

The story is about Winston and Julia and how they rebel against Big Brother. It was an interesting read in that it is still relevant to today. I kept thinking of North Korea during the book and how it seemed like what it is like there to an extent. I kept going back to see when it was written as it could have been written recently which was interesting.

The issue? I couldn't connect with any of the characters. I didn't care what happened to Winston or Julia. The whole love affair with them was so strange to me. I didn't understand it and it was just over the top. The way it was written just didn't work for me. I can't figure out exactly why, but I just didn't care about the characters. I still found it an interesting read. I just wish I would have connected more.

This review was originally posted to Jen in Bookland

review_headline: Great book, many commonalities with todays times.
review_body: Very good book, many parallels with the events of present day. Although the middle is very slow, if you push through it, you will be glad you did.
Therefore I cannot submit any info. Actually the thought police already are trying to contact me.Maybe I have been dissolved and just don't know it.
It was long, redundant and depressing.  And unlikely.  Orwell apparently had no faith in the human spirit.  Life will always out.

Mr. Snowden's revelations about the NSA and CIA listening and monitoring e-mails, phone calls and whatever caused our book club to turn to Mr. Orwell's classic vision of thoughtcrime, newspeak, doublespeak, and all of that terrible stuff.  The story would have been better without the latter half where our protagonist is subjected to all kinds of electronic pain at the hands, better say electrodes, of the one O'Brien his erstwhile friend.  I thought Dustin Hoffman strapped into Laurence Olivier's dental chair while his torturer performed the equivalent of a root canal on him was the worst it could get,  but I will accept the Orwellian methods as worst ever.  Of course the whole thing is absurd.  As our reviewer opined,  "The book never accomplished anything, it was zippo."  But did Eisenhower's "military-industrial complex"  accomplish anything?  I guess not, but it is repeated incessantly when the subject comes up, just as people know what Big Brother means.  Maybe its been good for our subconscious, who knows really?- - The discussion wended its way to J. Edgar Hoover and his enemy's files; Nixon and his list; Joe McCarthy's intimidations: Snowden's astounding leaks; and all the other hidden wars, clandestine CIA moves and that sort.  I give the book three stars perhaps because, having read it long ago, it seems like old stuff, especially the psychobabble at the end.  Nevertheless I recognize it as a classic and a book that should be read.

review_headline: A brilliant imagination - even if a bit dark
review_body: Captures the mood of that generation. A mirror to the philosophical conflict that had gripped the world back then. Read this if you want to imagine what might have been the fate of our world if the course of time had turned a little different post the 2 world wars.

review_headline: Even more thought provoking as an adult
review_body: I read this book the first time in 1984 & it was on of those books that stays in your head.  Back then it was  because of the technology Orwell created.  Telescreens, memory holes and Newspeak blew my mind.  Now it is the fact that I now know the evil that men have done, and will continue to do, all for the sake of power.  This book is not a novel as much as it is a life lesson for all us 94 percenters.  If you're OK with letting the government tell you what, when, how  much of anything you can have in your life then progressivism is the way to go.  As for me, I'll die happily with a gun in my hand defending my 84 oz big gulp.
I did not finish this book. It is very tender in the making and I'm enjoying it very diligently. And Scene.

I find it amazing the author wrote this all BEFORE any of these things were even invented!  What foresight!  Not only to have imagined that cameras and videos with recording devices would be monitoring you but the whole concept of big brother which exists is astonishing.  In Vietnam they have booming loud speakers in the middle of the night that sends out propaganda messages and people simply disappear never to be seen again. You must also be very careful what you say. This is only one example of MANY! George Orwell was amazing to put this together in an era where technology like this existed only in the future.

review_headline: Great insights regarding freedom and government
review_body: This books gives a glimpse of what are the repercussions of certain type of thinking with regards to the role of government in our lives. What's scary is that there are lot of things here that have an uncanny resemblance to what a lot of modern societies are living nowadays...

review_headline: The First Dystopia... is a Little Dull
review_body:
Here we are. The book which every other dystopia novel spans from. The king of the forbidden future. The first and foremost fallen future. 1984 by George Orwell.

I almost feel like the “Miss America” theme song should be playing. Or the overzealous Hunger Games announcer should be bubbling about the beauty of the book. Either way, 1984 is kind of a big deal.

So why did I need an extra shove to begin the book? Why did it take me so long to muster the courage to write its review?

Well, I have a secret. I didn’t like it.

It was only a matter of time before I read this famous book and became acquainted with the infamous Big Brother. I continually told myself I’d read it eventually, so when 1984 made itself a spot on my book club list, I knew it was time to stop procrastinating.

I read and read and read. It took me about two weeks to finish the book; I was fooled by the thin spine. Upon opening the books, I realized you practically need a magnifying glass to read the words and the margins were nonexistent. Even so, I powered through.

The real problem I had were the characters. I’m big on characters I can connect with. In 1984, I didn’t care about them at all. During their torture and their happiness, I felt nothing towards Winston and Julia. Not one thing. Since I wasn’t fond of the people, I didn’t care about their story.

Also, I didn’t think the world was all that original. I know, I know, put it in perspective. Back in Orwell’s day, this plot concept was unread of. And all those other dystopian novels I’ve read are really just based off of 1984. Since this is the case, I don’t see why we still hold the book to such high regard. I’m sure it has tons of literary value, but just because it was the first doesn’t mean it’s the best.

If you don’t know what 1984 is about: Winston is an average guy with an ordinary office job. He lives in the year 1984, or so he thinks. The world has changed since 1949 when Orwell wrote the book. And not for the better. 1984 holds no freedom of any kind for the people. Big Brother, the government, keeps a keen eye on all; they even patrol your thoughts. No one is safe, and all rebellion is blown to smithereens for fear of torture, or worse.

What the heck was Orwell thinking when he wrote this book!? The entire globe has dismissed the old way of thinking and has embraced total ignorance and essentially slavery. How did he think in 35 years the world would end up like that? During book club, someone brought up the point that technology was accelerating at an alarming pace due to the Cold Ware and WWII, so Orwell may have assumed the innovations would keep coming. Then again, he could have just exaggerated to prove a point, but it seems ridiculous to me.

Sure, the symbolism, the figurative language, blah, blah, blah… makes this a great book and a must read. I do admit it to be a book I think everyone should read in order to become culturally aware and to prevent this terrible future. But in my uneducated opinion, it’s boring.
1984 is a great read to open up your eyes to the great lengths that men in power will go to get & keep the average person under their thumb.  Very telling, great warning & insight.
interesting story but a little boring and too much reading in the book of the brotherhood. I would have liked a happier ending.

review_headline: There's so much truth to it in 2014 also!
review_body: For a novel that was written in 40s, George imagined the future very well and weaved his imagination around the oppression convincingly!

Given the current level of governmental intrusion into the public and private lives of its citizens, George Orwell's  1984, is a thought provoking read - The book  has been  considered to be a masterpiece by many and I count myself among them -

This is a must read title for the lovers of creepy books.
If you don't read this you missed out on something amazing
Always relevant classic that inspires and terrifies at the same time.  Would recommend it to anyone and especially to political science students.

review_headline: Shallow in plot, Deep in Thoughts
review_body: This book requires you to constantly remind yourself of when it was written and the condition of the world at that time.  The lack of details or memories  is overpowered by the deepness of thought required to try to understand the thoughts of the future.  I would only recommend it to someone who is a deep thinker of men and their ways.

review_headline: Deja Vu All Over Again-Orwell Saw This America Coming
review_body: This was a timely re-read, and matched perfectly to the Orwellian world of progressive America.  It's both funny and heart breaking to read what was suppose to be a far out satire, framed by its fruition in Mr. Obama's America.  If you read it before or this is the first time, you will be chilled to the bone as you read exactly what is happening now!  Fiction is truth.

We are now living 1984!!

I read this book when it first became available. I kept thinking that this could never happen in the USA! Now I realize that the worst HAS happened. It's terrifying!! The government knows everything about us!! So does other entities thru our credit cards, etc. Nothing is sacred anymore!! Start praying!!

This book was recommended to me by a friend, and I'm glad he did.  It is a very dark story, but it definitely gives you some things to think about.  The "Big Brother" concept is something that most people don't think can happen.  Reading a book like this, even though it's fiction, gives rise to the idea that it actually could happen. Today, with the liberal thinking of some, we are all in danger of this futuristic idea that left unchecked could become a reality. Security systems that people are putting into their homes right now, are very much like the ones installed in the homes of the future in this book, where everything you do is watched by Big Brother.  There is a lot of truth in fiction. I would recommend this book to anyone who is interested in futuristic stories about a government out of control.

Orwell creates an entirely different world, makes you see it from the view of a sane person and then shows you just how different it can be in the eyes of an insane one. Or vise versa, depending on your view. Brilliant.

While the story refers to specific period the author chose it can very well refer to current time and country still
led by tyrants.

It is an interesting book, especially considering the view of the future from 1949, just after WWII. There are so many aspects of the new society which can be seen in the World today and possibly always will be. The need for those in power to inflict pain and suffering sounds like North Korea. The fact that those who control the present control the past and, if you control the past, you control the future seems to be the motto of the current Australian government.
Possibly it needs to be read more than once to get all the concepts presented.
Very intelligent book.
First time reading this book. Very profound and relevant for today. I highly recommend this book if you haven't read it yet.

This really is quite a volume to get through.
Can be tedious and wordy. However, these elements are necessary in order to fully explain the social and societal systems etc.
This is a book that will challenge ones thoughts on society and politics and hopes for the future.
I would recommend reading this book again at different stages in your life.
Teens, 20s, 30s, 40, etc, will all gleen something different from this masterpiece.
Orwell is an incredible mind and puts it on display full in this volume.
I have just finished it and have closed the cover until another 20 years has passed.
I highly recommend reading this work and broadening your mind.

review_headline: My daughter was required to read 1984 for school...
review_body: ...so she asked me to read it, too. She said her classmates were not enjoying it. I didn't enjoy it.
I loved this book!  I never read it in school. It's so disturbing, it's great.  Makes me happy of the society I live in.

I feel like I waited way to long to purchase and read this book. The parallels between the events in this book and the way things are headed now in reality are frighteningly similar. You have to take into account when this book was written and how the author had no way of knowing about a lot of the technology we currently have. This is one of those books that you will spend a lot of time thinking about after you have read it. I know that I did. Highly recommend this book.

review_headline: This is the one book that must be read by all, it is summed up in one word, Masterpiece.
review_body: Set in a futuristic dystopian authoritative society that somehow seems eerily familiar, the book is divided into three parts each containing various chapters. The first part sets up the world in which Winston is confined and how he regards it. The second part allows Winston hope as he finds a companion with whom to endure the unbearable reality in which he is confined. After completing the second part of this book you will know undoubtedly that you will undeniably finish this book, and will lose any doubt concerning whether this tale will be one of the greatest you may read. In the third and final part Winston pays the ultimate price for dissent and has that which is impregnable taken from him, not his life but his essence. In conclusion this is one of the best books ever written, if not the greatest.
Eerily similar to what is believed to be happening in the country north of where I am.  Fascinating story line.

review_headline: What can I say?  Well deserved Classic
review_body: If you are in the mood for a dark, depressing tale that has very few bright moments, this is the book for you.  A wonderful tale of politics and control, whose themes resonate today like they did when it was written.  This book, while hard work, and really depressing, is a must read.

A book like this allows us to look at ourselves more closely.  While we may think the tortures are reductions to the absurd, are they any different than the pressures we feel each day.  This book possibly provides a foreshadowing of the events we live in each day with the integration of social media and it's continual monitoring of our lives.  Do we come to love the illusion?
Great read, don't conform to society. Threw a loop, and the ending is quite confusing until you pick up the context clues.

I picked up this book knowing a little bit about it already, although I had not (and still haven't) seen the film. But I really enjoyed the read! The language is really good, and it's funny to notice the small hints that sometimes show what time-period it was written in.

I would recommend 1984 to others :)
Very current days book.
This was worth re-reading and certainly provided food for thought in modern society. The telescreens and surveillance are quite eerie.
Fantastic. Suddenly fantastic. What a great book. Much wow. Such words. Fast knowledge. Great book. More story. Magnificent. So compelling

A book worthwhile to read in your spare time. The story can be so engaging that you may want to read it all at once.
You can rise many questions about its content. The most intriguing ones could be "Is the story about past or present times?", "Aren't we (nowadays) living similar episodes?", ...

review_headline: A classic distopia, in all it senses.
review_body: A classic distopia, in all it senses. Instigating and prone to make one reavaluate the role of social rigths and liberties.

A literary genius,writes about what is happening now.I read this in high school(1974)as a requirement.Although I wrote a paper on it I had not realized this has in a sense already began with our government,moving ever so slowly towards socialism.
I SIGN OF THE TIMES NOW.GREAT PERCEPTTION OF. POLITICAL CONSEQUENCES. SHOULD WAKE UP America. PAY ATTENTION TO POLITICS ,and  GOV.

the characters.. the themes.. all of it, brilliant.
his struggle is real and this story stands to teach us something important.

review_headline: Fiction has never seemed so real
review_body: Fiction has never seemed so real. If we don,t know history we will keep making the same mistakes over and over.
Great book. Has a lot of parralels to today's world. Scary!!!  Read it. You will not be disappointed. George Orwell was a genius.
George Orwell should be tried for what he provided ..... A 101 to dictatorship , sheer brilliance and outstanding vision of today's totalitarian regimes

If you've never read this book then you owe it to yourself to read it. A lot of ideas we say or have about government come from this book.

It is fiction, but it is frighteningly accurate in predicting events that can or have happened.

I shouldn't even say things like this here because we all know...

BIG BROTHER IS WATCHING ME...
Great book to read! I really enjoy Orwell's books and social commentary and life. Id recommend this to everyone. 5 stars

Excellent writtig, it is extraordinary how Orwell had such a good insight in what could happen in the near future. We may not be living in a 1984 world but the resemblance of some aspects are just too alike. This is a must-read.

Fantastic read! A literary classic that will give you a look into what our world could become. It has a myriad of memorable quotes, and is written in a very personal way that gives you an in depth experience within the protaginists mind. Although it is not for the faint-hearted due to its brutally realistic portrayl of events, this really illustrates the urgency and consequences of Orwell's purpose. To conclude, I highly recomend 1984 as a must read. Enjoy!
it was interesting, but not my cup of tea. Seems to me like there was more he could have done to frustrate the party.

I watched the movie back in the 70's and it scared me to death. I didn't read the book till 2012 and wish I hadn't waited so long. It seems like what is happening now with all the spying on U.S. citizens and I've seen it happening since the 70's with camera's slowly being installed everywhere and all of us being watched through our credit and purchases. The overall theme of the book that we are being lied to will hit home with most people. Very creepy and a work that was way ahead of it's time.

Is a great book. It starts off slow then it picks up. I was surprise with The ending really didn't see it coming. If you a person who likes to see things different this book is for you. While reading this book I made a couple
Of connection to modern society now. So don't be scared to read it.
Glad to have re-read it after many many years. The government monitoring is coming true in many ways in our electronic world! Very interesting.
Finally got to get back and read this again, many years after high school. I have a much different perspective on life now, but the themes still can chill me to the bone.

I've been hearing about this book for a long time. And as I read it, there was a sort of ominous feel to the story. But as people asked what I was reading I quickly learned that people read into the store and get back they want to hear. So the story is genius as it appeals to everyone. But not exactly foretelling I don't think in our future.

There were a few good predictions, but all based on technology available at the time.
great book in every way.well written by a author ahead of his time.if we are not careful,also a vision of what our society may become.

review_headline: A very dark and thoughtful tale
review_body: Simply put, this is a story about the battle we wage not only with society, but also with ourselves. It is not happy, or hopeful, but it is an interesting take on human nature. I don't agree with it all, but it does make me wonder.
even thouhg the history is weird in terms of similar experiences the author made an incredible job relating it in a way that readers can believe it

I remember when this book used to be required reading. It should be still. Especially in these times, it's good to be reminded of where this kind of government eventually ends up as. Want to be taken care of the by those in charge? Be prepared to give up every original thought and every freedom you think you have.
Classic book that describes a world that will exist in the future.  A very depressing world, much of which has already come to exist
I had heard about this series and was hoping for more. I was not really impressed. Could have been better.
Seems like it to me. We are now living under a Corporate Charter type of government more than a constitutional type.
If you don't read this, you're dumb. Seriously, how can you pass up something like this? Don't be an idiot.

I would recommend this book to anyone who enjoys social commentary and the thought that comes with it.  Even though this book was published in 1949 there are some themes that are still relevant today.
Really thought provoking considering historical and modern governing attitudes and practices. Well written and captivating. Good read. A step up from Animal Farm.

review_headline: Not like I thought it would be
review_body:
I did not care for this book. There was too much attention , paid to the language of Big Brother and these perceptions of reality. It was
distracting to go in circles about love ,war,reality etc.
Undoubtedly one of the best books I've ever read, each time brings about more closure and comprehension on the intricately detailed and circularly planned plot. A true must read novel

review_headline: Change is not as Constant as you think.
review_body: Just read the news and it becomes clear . You look at it and you see how the more things change the more they stay the same.
Technical advances are being used to track where we are and what we are doing.The government maybe should reread. Really!

This book simply wasn't for me.  I started it, but from the beginning I found I just couldn't get into it.  I didn't care for the story line nor the writing.  I know many, many reviewers liked the book, but I did not.

Interesting themes presented in this book.
Definitely ahead of it's time.
Who was Mr Orwell channelling when he came up with this gem?
Well worth the read and definitely in my classic collection.

Since I first read this book, as a teen back in the 60's, I've been aware of the little changes in our thinking, values, laws, and politics here in the US. In the past few years I've seen it rapidly move into Orwell's vision of 1984.
I found the book very interesting, a very dark and gloomy view what the future my hold. Very much worth reading
It was definitely different than anything I've read.  Liked it until the end.  Didn't like how book ended; it was unsatisfying.

I hadn't read this for 30+ years. It was scary to see that a book written in 1948 could be so accurate to what is happening 65 years later!!!
A must read for anyone who is concerned about where we are heading!!

review_headline: Needed for research project, wanted for contents
review_body: One of my favorite books that no matter what always strikes a chord with me. I've read it a million times it seems, but everytime I open it, its like starting anew.
My mind was taken on a journey with this book and at the end of it I felt extremely enlightened and a little uneasy, because of the similarities between this book and the world we live in today.
Why did I put myself through this? Reading this was almost as torturous as going to room 101. Enough already.
I have this book in case any of those young no nothings question me as to how I can cannot trust our current administration and their NSA cronies.

People told me, "you MUST read 1984 because its just like today!!!!!!" And now that i read it, my answer to that is, Uhhh, no its not. Not even remotely close. Even North Korea and Islam-controlled nations aren't close to this book. No government will ever be like that. Humans would overthrow any government long before it got to that point. But besides the talk from conspiracy cuckoos or people living in some fantasy world, the book itself was so incredibly boring i am amazed i even finished it. They could have easily made it a 20 page short story and it still would have dragged on too long. One of the worst books i ever read. If you want a book about a controlling society, Animal Farm by this author is much better and actually more realistic... despite talking livestock! I would not recommend this book to my worst enemy.
George Orwell  was a prophet I guess.  Just look around ....  scary isn't it?  Read this book and get energized to make some changes.
One of the most frightening stories ever told. I've read it at least four or five times, and it never ceases to haunt.

There is a lot to be said about 1984, as well as Orwell's other works. This launched the entire genre of Dystopian Fiction. The undertones of the book apply just as much today as they did in 1948, when the book was written. It also serves as a warning and even a pointing arrow towards things going on this very day. It goes without saying that some of my own writing was, without a doubt, influenced by 1984.
This book is worth reading every 10 years just to get a jolt of caution about the world and where it is going. Every decade it looks more and more like Orwell had everything right except the timing.
Great reread would recommend it to everyone. I'm guessing when its required reading in high school it loses some of its value. Glad I took the time to down load and reread.

Orwell's 1984 maintains its ferocity and dysthmic energy even after 60 something years. His writing is palpable, visceral, conceptually layered and displays the fascination with language along the lines of Joyce or William S. Burroughs. This masterpiece is wasted on high schoolers and should be banned, only to generate more interest in it.

Very well written. I am definitely a fan of Orwell's style. I enjoyed the book overall but it is not something I would normally pick up at the book store! I mean i'm 18-- probably why i'm into YA novels ya know?

review_headline: Huge disappointment compared to Animal Farm
review_body:
I bought and read this book because it is an absolute classic. I had already read Animal Farm by the same author, and I loved Animal Farm.

1984 was a huge disappointment for me, considering how famous it is and how much I liked Animal Farm. It was exactly what I expected at every turn, to the point of being boring. It felt like the author was just ramming a political agenda down my throat. That agenda is "government surveillance is bad." I fully agree with that agenda, but I don't need to read a long polemic about it.

The plot and characters were not compelling. It was frankly boring in large swaths.
Weird book to real at times. But it really makes you think what life could be like. Wow weird hum

Great Story on my Iphone
Great story easy to read on my phone recommend it to anyone who wants to read it.

review_headline: A story that looks at what could be,potentially
review_body: A good Book about a future that Didn't Happen, but could.Gives a really bizzare Look at the future if we are not careful.

review_headline: At the end of a great book
review_body:
Having been robbed of reading this book in high school, I am happy to say that I have finally read it.

I felt myself change as the protagonist changed. I feared when he feared, I was filled with happiness when he was happy. Not many books can do that to you.

All in all, it is a great novel that everyone
should read once in their life.

This is a great book, but if you're a kind of fiction-, fantasy-loving book reader, I don't think this book is for you. However, its insight on political structure is amazing! I think it is a critical read for the youth of our age.

I really don't know what to say........
JUST READ THE BOOK
Orwell was a genius, and his book makes you question what you believe in about the extent of human evil and if human nature will reach this point by 2050.

1984 is an amazing book which is as relevant today as it was when it was written in the late 1940's.  The original dystopia/post-apocalyptic fiction.  This was my gateway drug into PA/Dystopia fiction and I keep comparing everything against 1984.  If you have note read it before, please do.  It is just one of those books everyone should read!~=
It wasn't what I expected exactly but very good nonetheless.  Thought It was funny cigarettes were still in the mix.

This dystopian masterpiece has stood the test of time.  I first read it while in high school and its effect on me was profound.  With our ever encroaching police state, I felt it was time to read it again 45 years later.  To me, Orwell's vision is more prescient than ever, although I think the society envisioned by Aldous Huxley in "Brave New World" may more accurately reflect where we are headed.
I have to read this book in my English Pre-Honors class & im sorry to say that it has been a dreadful time for me with this book. Im more than half way in the book and im hoping things will pick up.
From THE dystopian novel, I expected more. I would much prefer to read "Atlas Shrugged" or "Brave New World" for my dystopian fix.
A classic of its genre, 1984 is as applicable to today's society as when Orwell first put pen to paper.

This book should be a must read for everyone, even if only for a cultural reason, because Orwell's "1984" brought the terms 'Big Brother' and 'Orwellian' into common usage. It's message is not one to take lightly.

I read this for university and found it okay. It was not as bad as I expected but is still rather scary and intense!!
Here's hoping this future never eventuates... We're not so far away from it.
One of the must read books! I re-read it recently and compared to when I first read it about 15-years ago, found the messages deeper and even more thought provoking.
My only complaint is that I should have read this book earlier in my life when I had the chance. Classic.

review_headline: Labyrinth of blunt logic and horror
review_body: This is a must read for anyone who thinks that a government of man is to be trusted with anything.  In this book, the ruthless rendition of the horrible resolution of the world that is Oceania leaves the reader with absolutely no hope for the future within the context of the book.  Reading it is first suspenseful, then anxious and finally traumatic.  And I think that George Orwell intended this.  At the end I think he is much less concerned with being realistic as he is with bleeding out a theoretic nightmare to its conclusion.  The scary part about the finality of 1984 is that without an intervention of power that is above man, Orwell's rendition of the world that would inevitably result through man is like O'Brian both, hard to argue with and wickedly ugly... The book chokes you and provides no escape within itself.  But looking beyond, it's just a pouring out of one mans philosophy...  Take heed as you read and don't go crazy.
Still a great classic.  It's scary to see how the scenes in this book are more of a reality than Orwell probably thought.  This should be required reading for every kid.

Loved this book. Its really truly sad how the U.S. is going down the authoritarian path. It also goes to show that Big government socialism i.e. welfare is not the way to go. I would suggest reading "Power Divided is Power Checked: The Argument for States' Rights" after reading this book.

If only we moved to states rights could we actually see different economic ideas play out. Who knows maybe a limited socialistic economy with a federal government that protects that states rights from other states instead of intruding on state rights might actually work. Maybe a negative income tax would work or even we could just see plain old free-market capitalism working?

We've lost all experimentation in this country.
One of my favorite books that Orwell wrote on his deathbed. Knowing a bit about Orwell makes this classic even more interesting.
George Orwell has written a book that will most certainly always be relevant to humankind. A must-read, especially for the younger crowd who have yet to fully form their understanding of the world.
Absolutely incredible. It's like george Orwell had a crystal ball. Very thought provoking, but be careful, the thought police are watching you!

It a book that most high school student had to read.  Reading it a second time later in life is a good idea.  I have a greater appreciation of meaning of the book and what is happing in America today.
Brilliantly written. Very incisive. Dystopia written at it's best. Winston is every man, what we all think we would be in a similar situation.
After reading this book I can tell that most people who refer to the "Orwellian" world we are living in have never actually read the book.

Amazing how Orwell could predict so many things that sadly are coming to pass in
this country. I read it before but felt I should read it again

This was a chilling look into a future that isnt all that hard to see anymore. It amazes me how long ago this was written, and how relavent it is today. It should be required reading in high school. Lots of deep themes, and messages. “He who controls the past controls the future. He who controls the present controls the past.”

People should take the time to understand that "facts" they are fed in the media do not always tell the accurate or complete, or even true story sometimes. They are often built to sell ratings, and based on loose allegations or deception to sway opinion.

Think for yourself. Read a book. This a good one to start with.

I guess I am stating the obvious when I say how insightful this book is. It is a reflection of the era it was written in, but also is a cautionary tale about what this could mean for society in the future. It is amazing that even in 2013 it is still a cautionary tale...a fantastic read.

This story has affected me more than almost any other that I have read. Not because I enjoyed it (I did, but that is not why I write this), but because the world of 1984 horrified me beyond anything I have ever known in fiction, and even in reality.

I give this book five stars for not only making me question the validity of human existence, but for making me truly dread that a world like this could ever exist, fictional or not.

The paradigms in which this book builds and then contradicts are absolutely mind blowing. Any novel that can evoke emotion earns high regards in my mind, thus giving this book in particular one of the highest, for its ability to make me love so blissfully and hate so deeply. It's a excellent read for those who like the challenge of thought.

review_headline: The most prescient piece of literature in modern history
review_body: This book is more relevant today than ever. It is a must read if one is to come to grips with what identity and freedom mean in the age of information.

I did not finish this book.  After t wo chapters, I recognized that it was just too dark, so I deleted it from my Kindle.  Sorry bout t that for you folks who are quite naturally looking for good words.

review_headline: Cool and interesting with many twists and turns
review_body: This is a wonderful book, showing many interesting views of power and control. George Orwell is an expert at describing these kinds of things, so this book is perfect.
It was mostly good. Some over emphasizing of terms and going in too much of things that weren't too terribly relevant. And I didn't like the ending. It was abrupt and sudden.
amazing perspective, engaging, unparalleled quotes, and makes you think. What more can you ask from a book? Highly recommend to anyone and everyone.

review_headline: Why did it take me so long to finally read this book?
review_body: I have heard about this book for most of my life, but I never got around to reading it until now. I'm glad I finally read it. It gave me a lot to think about.

review_headline: Are social and cultural singularity possible?
review_body:
[...]

George Orwell's answer to this question is ambiguous. On the one hand, 1984 ends in singularity. There is no outside. There is no determinate contradiction. On the other hand, he is the author of a provocation, demonstrating at the very least differentiation within, but also perhaps determinate contradiction within what is no longer a singularity. But this invites us to critically reflect on the social location of this dissident place \\"outside\\" the frame? What is the new frame that includes both these places? What has been left untheorized or undertheorized in 1984?
With the way our government currently acts, this book scared the heck out of me.  It was written some time ago, but it could be applied today with frightening similarities.

1984 is an amazing book with a chilling socio-political commentary about the bottom of a depressing slippery slope of surveillance.
11/10 will read again.
I read this book that my son had to read to English.  I found it very depressing and definitely not the ending I would have wanted.

The novel provides analogous glimpses of current events. Having lived through the Cold War it is easy to see how 1984 had the impact it did when published.

Clearly the technology exists that would provide constant surveillance and the conspiracy theorists are happy to illustrate how it is happening in today's context. Possibly the NSA is today's Big Brother.
Beautifully written in causal words while describing difficult to understand concepts of being watched everyday which is the reality we live today.

This book took me a few months to read because of its few dull moments and my hectic schedule, but it was definitely worth it. It's amazing that Orwell had such an imaginary in his time period to envision such a world. 5 stars.

Orwell's Newspeak equals Political Correctness. His Ingsoc equals our modern progress toward socialism in America. Big Brother and the Thought Police are analogous to our current government and the NSA. You ARE being watched and listened to, and EVERYTHING is recorded! The Party and the Proles are analogous to our modern Political Class verses the Working Class. Orwell shows how government cares not about the people, but only about itself and remaining in power, even if it means rewriting or even DELETING history to remain in control. Think Common Core! It's a difficult read at times, to be sure, as Orwell lays out his ideas and sentiments, but DO NOT let yourself, your family and your friends end up like Winston and Julia! Keep yourself abreast of current events, listen with a critical mind and READ THIS BOOK!!! I waited WAY too long to do it. Oh, and by the way, it's also tragic and entertaining!
Great read when I was in high school back in the eighties. An even better read now that Big Brother is entering every aspect of our lives.

Many of my friends read \\"1984\\" when I was in college in the late 60's - early 70's, but I did not. So, as a close watcher of current politics, I decided to read it now.
In my opinion, \\"1984\\" is an absolute MUST READ for all, but especially High Schoolers and College Students. I wouldn't be surprised if it were not stripped from all public schools, because they have become the exact replicas of the propaganda, brainwashing and indoctrination institutions of the Party in power now in this country. The complicit media, willing to do the bidding of those in power. The constant forcing of citizens to adhere to Political Correctness, Doublespeak, the marginalization of Christians, Conservatives, and anyone else who holds to social norms or disagrees with the party line.
This is one of the most depressing books I have ever read because it is exactly what is happening in our world. It is the same story of Absolute Power as represented by other epic novels such as \\"Lord of the Rings\\", the Ring possessing the power to bind all others.
As O'brien told Winston Smith, the party didn't want the power so they could \\"help\\" others, they wanted it for the purpose of POWER. Chilling, but that is what is happening.
Orwell displays amazing insight in drawing totalitarian, one party rule to it's diabolical conclusion.

This is a great book that every American citizen should read.  I understand that it used to be required for school reading - and I think it should still be.  It's very interesting that this author had such a foresight of what "could happen" if we do not defend our constitutional rights.

review_headline: This Is A Great Work Of Science Fiction??
review_body: I thought the book droned on and on.  I found it as boring as sitting at one slot machine in Vegas for days on end.
Seems to mirror our current government situation. I wanted to read this book for many years but never made time for it.

review_headline: Is this the fate of America with the Obama Administration?
review_body: Although George Orwell wrote this based on the Soviet Union experience, there is still a threat today of a tyrannical government creating its own "truths" about history and the use of sadistic brain washing tactics to complete complete control over the "Party Faithful."  The anti-hero of this book was in a position of "correcting" history to lead people to believe that the Party's view of history was real and he had a problem in that he remembered some history that was not in accordance with the Party's version and had, in fact been a part of the process of erasing the truth and exchanging it for a lie.  We are in the same danger with our media expressing a slanted version of the "truth" and with over 48% of the citizens dependent on the government for their subsistence, they can perpetuate the lie,  The sad fact is that a large percent of Americans have created a myth of a super big brother attitude about Obama.  To most of them his dictatorial approach to government ("we are not negotiating unless you totally surrender your position") now seems right.  Big Brother perpetuates the lie with constant wars, statistics of growth and destruction of home and family.  The saddest part of the whole book is when our anti-hero gives up his humanity and discovers that he loves Big Brother and the system that stripped him of dignity, humanity, love and left him a drunken sod swilling cheap gin and no ambition.
It is very thought-provoking.  Hopefully, Americans will not allow this to happen to our civilization. Winston and Julia had a tough time.

review_headline: A book eveeryone has probably read, and should re-read.
review_body: I am enjoying reading this for the second time.  I,m finding it very interesting and thought provoking even the second time around.
We need to be dry aware of where our passions take us...or do we? Should we just let the mind take us away to a base pae?

I decided to re-read 1984 to see how it fit in to the current situation in our society. I was dismayed to find that it is as timely as ever and equally as frightening. There are pages of the book that could come from today's newspaper and sections describing torture and brainwash that might as well have been about Guantanamo. Amazing that Orwell got so much right about how things would develop way back in the 1940s. Well worth reading again, and again and again...
Must to read, a book contain the deep thoughts that are going on long after the story is over. This book will change your thoughts...
Ha d to read this book in high school but didn't appreciate it until 40yrs later, will read more high school books.

review_headline: Predicted the future of American Government
