review_body: It happened not in 1984, but in 2008, when the Government of The USA decided that the people were no longer capable of taking care of themselves.  It was up to the all knowing Government  to take care of everyone, because the government knew what was best for the people.

review_headline: It is a classic cautionary tale.
review_body: It's a classic, but I can't say that I really enjoyed it. It was easy to read though and I found myself returning to it quickly whenever I had time to read.

Great book. It follows the life of a working man who has an ability that most other people around him seem to not have, the ability to think for himself. With this he gets himself into trouble with the government who is constantly watching everyone's every move. Has some great twist on love, friendship, betrayal, government surveillance, and overall government control. Great read highly recommend it.

1984 is a fictional book which brings a world of fright and hatred in which the main character lives in a latent state of rebellion. It is just exhilarating and must be read by anyone who likes books.

We seem to be fast arriving at this state in our present government. Spying, ignoring the Constitution and vast numbers of our citizenry totally unaware and ignorant of what's happening. Will America wake up in time?
Every American should read 1984 and watch the German film, "the Lives of Others."  Both are stunningly and frighteningly accurate
This novel is more relevant than it's ever been.  Orwell was off by a generation, but he clearly saw the future as it could be if we're not VERY thoughtful and careful.

I first read this 30 years ago in school.  At the time my teacher said that she would read it every 5 years and was shocked at how much closer to this reality we are getting.  At the time I shrugged off what she said.  Now I see what she meant.  Not only is this book a cautionary or prediction tale, it's beautifully written.  Take a few minutes just to look at the language of the first couple of pages.  Orwell appeals to all of our senses to bring us into the story.
The new generations should read this book; even if you've read it before, it bears reading again considering today's world. It sparks a primitive fear.......
Horribly boring! My daughter asked me to read it with her. She is reading it for Honors English,,,,,poor thing! Would not recommend this to anyone.

review_headline: Too close to our present reality!
review_body: I found this book "creepy" reading it for the 2nd time for book club.  It is too close to the reality of what we are experiencing presently under this administration and ever increasing government regulations and intervention into our lives.  It was a awake call for all of us who value community, freedoms, and the meaning of our constitution.  We are being "brainwashed" by the mainstream media and our government with "the speak" efforts.  Very scary!

After finishing this book, which became a chore at times, I needed to enjoy some REALLY good books by C.S. LEWIS. 1984 depicts a world that is an all out worst case scenario to say the least. We are not there yet, thank God!

Here's something you don't see everyday: a more or less negative review of 1984. Let me be clear; it's not a bad book. But once you consider how much people tend to hype this up, and constantly refer to it as an example of what would happen if we let fear force us to give up our civil liberties, this book is over the top. Seriously, the dictatorship in this book makes the Nazis look like the Peace Corp. Fake wars, mind control, and cameras in your toilet are some of the things citizens in 1984 have come accept as normal. Seem far fetched? It is.

If you can look past the in-your-face political agenda of this book, then the story is OK. The protagonist is not exactly an interesting or personable character, and while intentional, makes the book more work than pleasure. If you want to read it for the story, fine, but don't ever take this as a serious look into society. Do yourself a favor and read Orwell's Animal Farm instead, which is essentially a book about the same concept except crafted much more artfully. If you must read something about a utopia with an oppressive society, get Brave New World by Aldous Huxley. Much better story overall in my opinion, with a more subtle and relevant political message.
It's a good book it's older I had to read it in high school did like it then but like it now
I read 1984 in high school and had the impression "yeah, sure!" With the landscape of today, I felt like I needed to reread the story and it's as relevant for today.

Orwell finished this book in 1947. In his novel he dealt with people whose every thought and movement was known by the government. Each apartment had a camera so there was never a time the government didn't know what you were doing.Having opinions apart from the government could result in torture, death or breaking of a person't spirit. I found this book troubling. It leaves you with a lot to think about.

review_headline: A classic that everyone should read
review_body: The imagined dangers of a complex society. but as technology continues to advance it is amazing how much the threats portrayed in this book become more possible without all the bureaucracy. As we switch to a more and more digital world and hard copy paperback starts to fall to the wayside with a keystroke and an auto correct massive amounts of record could be changed or wiped out.

I read this book because I knew it to be an important piece of literature and so I thought I should.  It certainly has a level of interest, a warning in its portrayal of society and government.  Much of the book read as a lesson book in both ideology and behavior.  It was dark and depressing and at certain times relentlessly stagnant and I suppose it was meant to be.  I'm glad I read it and I will certainly spend some time absorbing and evaluating the messages within the text and between the lines.  I can claim an appreciation but I can't say that I exactly enjoyed the book.
Strangely coincides the mediated society we are living on today. Orwell was on to something.  I understand why We are reading this book for my media effects on society class.

Capturing people's thoughts and punishing them for it is terrifying to say the least.  The frst half of the book describes the world from a 1949 point of view, after WWII.  It predicts future abilities in 1984 of the ruling party to control the masses of people to do their will, whether by threats, torture, or mind control.  The main character is aware of the culture and tries to get beyond it, despite the massive impediments. Difficult to read.

review_headline: Scary!!!  - Do not read if you want your eyes open.
review_body: The parallels to modern society are shocking, especially when you realize this book was written 60 years ago. We did not even have computers at that point. We didn't have calculators. The foresight Orwell had when writing this is obscenely creepy. He knew what we were headed for before we were even headed in this direction. BEST BOOK I have read this month. WOW.

Disturbingly prophetic, The current events starting from the last decade to the present in the media, military, government, the spy programs, the loss of privacy, Spying on private citizens, are all mirrored in 1984, Shocking that we have allowed our sacred freedom to be slaughtered & sold off... 1984 is now.
I had heard so much about this book I expected something better. In reality I had to force myself through it.
i definitely suggest this book for reading. it`s the kind of book that will leave you feeling all sorts of different range of emotions

kinda scary...that George Orwell knew what was coming.  big brother watching and controlling everyone and everything.  Maybe it is time for the people to overthrow the government, after all, our president seeme to support it when the people of other countries revolt,lets see what he thinks when Americans do it!
Prognostic for the dawn of WW II.  Makes me wonder what we're reading today that will be similarly prophetic. Plot device if the main character reading Orwell's tenets was straining.

It is scary to think George Orwell could so accurately depict the world under the absolute rule of a totalitarian government and could so predict the direction of the world today.  This should be on everyone's reading list.

Classic dystopian lines that make you interested in this Big Brother world,and where power of this party rules the roost. One has every detail of life monitored,and is much like how our society is spied upon. This has a prophetic influence  included , and it is written by the George Orwell himself.
I decided to finally read this book after holding it off since middle school. Very much enjoyed the enlightenment. This book was great.

review_headline: Very interesting and a tad unnerving!
review_body: Very interesting read.  Kind of uncanny how the author foresaw the way some things could and would turned out for us.  When I read this as a teenager, I thought it was pretty intense and farfetched, now in my late fifties I am kind of freaked out how some things have actually turned out for us today.  It is way scarier than it was in 1974, when I read it the first time.

I am amazed at the imagination of George Orwell who wrote this book in 1948.  It is spooky that so much of this government intervention has come to pass of late, but I hope we are still a LONG way from the world of "1984".  It is a very gripping read with a somewhat gruesome ending!

review_headline: Has anyone NOT read this yet?
review_body:
Update # 2
It's been over a year now since I read 1984 and I can't get it out of my mind. I didn't like it much when I read it...I still don't like the outcome, but you have to admire any book that haunts you like this one does. Orwell's ability to make me think about this story so consistently for such a long period of time is a credit to his greatness. It has become the book I love to hate and for that it gets another star.

Update
So I have had a month to consider this book. I find myself thinking about it a fair amount. I now think the point of this book was to make people become outraged at the story. To use this story as a way to incite people to fight against Government control. To not let things get close to becoming this way. Since it was written around the time of war, Orwell may have sensed that the Government might consider using the war as an excuse to tighten the reigns on the population. Anyhow, if a book keeps me thinking like this book has, it gets an extra star.

Original Review
To put it bluntly, and probably much to the dismay of many, I did not like this book. It was monotonous for the first few chapters - which I think was probably the point. The rest was OK until I got to the end. I'm not sure what the author was trying to say. Perhaps \\"Just give up, you can't beat the Government\\" or \\"Give up on striving for anything, it won't happen in the end\\" or even \\"Every person is so insignificant that they might as well end it all now\\". One might think the Government itself paid the author to put that out to make a point. In the end, to me, it doesn't matter. I didn't like the message that I read in it.

Great read. Be prepared to see the parallels...I re-read this book because of all of the hubbub surrounding the question of personal privacy issues. Much of the content really hits the nail on the head. Enjoy!!
Every Student should read this classic. One of George Orwell's best works if not THE best. Something that seemed so impossible to happen when I read it as a teenager is now a fact of life...

I highly recommend this book to anyone who values their personal freedom. I first read this book in the early 1960's and did not think too much of it at the time. I am a law abiding, responsible person who loves the USA and am not part of any conspiracy group or movement.
The book was published in 1949 and was required reading for a college level Political Science course I took in the early 1960's. Although we knew it was a work of fiction, our instructor likened it to life in a \\"totalitarian communist or socialists\\" country. The life described in the book was totally foreign to life in a free republic like the U.S. Now, fast-forward fifty years to current political realities of life in the U.S. and one must conclude that Orwell was a prophet of the Moses class. Were we told in 1960 that our government would one day own or control major U.S. industries such as; banking, mortgage, insurance, automotive, health care and energy we would think the person making such a claim was totally uninformed or in need of psychiatric care. On top of outright ownership or control is the added influence exerted on private businesses by government rules and regulations and it becomes easy to see that \\"1984\\" is now more fact than fiction.
The traditional \\"free enterprise, capitalists\\" system seems to have given way to the concept of \\"redistribution of wealth\\". Even salaries paid within private corporations, in some instances, is controlled by government.
As if that wasn't enough, within the past year, our trust in government has been further undermined by learning that government agencies trusted with our most private and sensitive personal information (think IRS) have punished people for their political views as well as shared private information with other governmental and private organizations in violation of established law and regulations.
The most recent cause for a healthy skepticism about our government follows the disclosure that the National SecurityAgency has been collecting untold amounts of phone, email and other electronic data on the communications of law abiding citizens without warrants or justification. This coupled with the GPS tracking system causes one to wonder; just how much surveillance is really necessary?
Like Orwell's 1984, our government officially makes promises it does not or cannot keep. What was once the truth, now by virtue of political correctness, becomes hate speech. Religious thought is criticized and demeaned and is being forced from the public square. Government redefines or excludes certain traditional words from public discourse.
Although I encourage anyone who desires to know about our founding principles to read any number of good books by our founding fathers, I believe it would do us all good to read Orwell's 1984. Although a work of fiction it unfortunately rings very true.

review_headline: Weird and depressing, but still a classic
review_body: The ending is not happy and it makes the entirety of the plot sort of irrelevant. Winston lead a troubled life throughout and never achieves anything against big brother. It is definitely interesting though.
I had to read this book for school, and I was absolutely amazed. How could I cry while reading this, but not during Les Miserables? Haha

Pros:
- Keeps to the big picture, even through the details.
- Accurately portrays a dystopian society
- Constantly engaging. Creates and maintains a sense of peril and danger throughout
- Has a refreshingly cruel ending
- The repressive atmosphere correctly displays the levels of greed that the average man portrays even under constant surveillance and stress

Cons:
- The romantic subplot was fairly unfulfilled... but it was meant to be rather bland

I just read this book for the the first time since high school over twenty years ago. I was able to understand so much more.  I want to recommend this to everyone again.  The ways of controlling society are real and present in our reality. Geniuses.

Today's politics lean towards 1984 in many ways. Not so much in totalitarianism but the absolute absorption of certain people into political dogma. Denial of science, history, facts, common sense, and believing in a reality that is crafted by their masters. No diversion from the ideology is tolerated. Heretics are purged through purity tests. The sane are labeled insane. A constant drift towards less tolerance and more brutality to the those who are not part of the Party. Doublethink is in full force today in many places and the faithful embrace Slavery as Freedom.

Orwell was prescient about the future, he was just a few years off. Read 1984 in this context, and it will chill you to the bone.
Many things were rushed but had a good story line. I liked this book and I recommend it as a high school level.

review_headline: It is a must read, but it is also aged and shallow
review_body: This book is part of our culture now, the quotes from it are famous and often used. And indeed, the best part of the story is the description of how twisted PR can be and how ridiculous such a twisted PR actually is. In this sense it is a distant cousin of Chaplin's Dictator. On the other hand, Orwell had some aspiration for explaining a totalitarian society and on this account he fails.  Much better artistic explorations of totalitarian systems were created with much deeper understanding of human nature and society. The movie Mephisto comes to my mind, but the examples are numerous. Probably the only insight in the book is that absurd PR has no chance of succeeding without thorough surveillance.
I reread this book because of current events.  Am still amazed at the insight Mr.Wells had when he wrote the book.  Even though it is clearly fiction it gives a very clear warning for today.

review_headline: 1984 Almost Quaint by Today's Privacy Violations
review_body: Reading George Orwelll's 1984 in post Edward Snowden America is almost surreal. Perhaps Orwell foresaw that Britain would wield surveillance like an unrestrained weapon, with London boasting more CCTV cameras than any other city in Europe. But he couldn't have guessed that the degree of surveillance he imagined in his worst nightmares, when he wrote the book, would be so easily surpassed by an out-of-control NSA in the United States. Nor that for the sake of convenience or a delusional sense of security, people would be so willing to reveal their every last thought to Big Brother simply by an appeal to their egos. Today's Big Brother need not to worry about formerly-illegal eavesdropping to capture "thought criminals" or flag their Google searches. Or torture without the threat of prosecution or sanction. He just needs to read their tweets. If he has the patience.
Replacement of one I had in high school. Good reading again, Pretty much had forgotten what it was about. Read it.

review_headline: Chilling Picture of Life Under Total Government
review_body: Much of what Orwell described in his futuristic 1949 novel is now reality.  He wrote about flat "telescreens" that hung on walls like pictures, unthinkable in 1949.  Today of course, we take flat screen TVs for granted.  He described government Thought Police who punished citizens for thinking the wrong thoughts.  Today we have "political correctness."  He described an all-powerful, super invasive government snooping on citizens around the clock.  Today we have the NSA recording all our electronic communications, plus the CIA, FBI, IRS and a host of other agencies prying into every corner of our lives.  Read and decide for yourself the degree to which Orwell's Ministries of Truth, Love, Plenty and Peace describe the world in which we live.

I was never a fan of Animal Farm, so I naturally stayed away from Orwell, but Spy-gate sucked me in.  I thought it was a very interesting storyline, although it seemed to be three separate stories inserted and loosely retied at the end.  Regardless, it kept me intrigued.  I thought Orwell's vision of this futuristic world eerily relates to much of the technology we possess, allowing the conspiracy theorist to conclude we are in-fact living in the early stages of "1984"

This book is mind twisting and causes one to question reality. What is reality? Does it even matter if, say, everything occurs in one's own imagination?  A lot of questions arise from reason this book but at the same time, some questions are answered as well. It is all under your own perception of the book.
I like it so far, but I'm only half way thru the book.  I'll write a review when I finish reading the book.

This is a classic and a must read ! Try this classic and others because books were great then and have a much different style then today. If you are into conspiracy and mystery then read this and remember how long ago it was written...it had me thinking about it and discussing it for days!

Welcome to the world of 1984, where the one and only goal of the ruling party is gaining more power and inflicting pain, making sure the entire population is obedient due to the party's own might - not due to the people's free well. A world with no emotion except fear, rage, triumph, and self-abasement. Everything else is destroyed, even the links between child and parent, between man and man, and between man and woman. No one dares to trust a child, a wife, or a friend anymore; there's no loyalty except loyalty toward the party, no love except the love of Big Brother, no laughter except upon a defeated enemy, no heart, no literature, no science, no beauty, and no curiosity. Only a world of fear and treachery and torment; a world that just grow more merciless by the day...

This was one of the darkest books I've read in a while, where even at the end, the main story character is defeated body and soul. It was a so powerful, touching, heartbreaking and thought provoking read.
Very disturbing to see some of the things I read were now reality.  Hard to believe it was written so long ago.

I little too depressing. I hope we will never see such a world as depicted in 1984 although one never knows. Recently the power of mass media over public opinion is becoming more and more frightening...
Wanted to like it more than I did. Love science fiction but just could not get into this one. Finished it.
A must read for all if they have any concerns about the direction of our great country.a real eye opener
Not the easiest read in the world, but well worth the slog.  There's so much in this book to think about, especially in regards to the world today.

A timely book for our current times.  Although this is a work of fiction, directed mainly at authoritarian governments following WW II, it has much that is applicable to us today.  1984 could happen any time.

review_headline: What can you say about this? It's a classic.
review_body: We are so far headed into the 1984 Orwell warned us about, I had to get the book to re-read so I could remember what I forgot when I read it the first time - scary stuff, but it is already happening. I wouldn't be surprised if writing this review didn't bring the black SUVs to my doorstep.
If you have not read George recently, do so now. George will help you understand government today. And that is without doubt sad but true.

A powerful novel written in 1949 about one man's view and experience from inside a dystopian society where the government spies on its citizens continuously to stifle dissent, maintains the citizens in a state of constant fear by fabricating enemies and wars and tortures it's citizens when they're found to have incorrect thinking.  George Orwell's haunting examination of the natural inclination to resist regimented control by all-powerful authority figures, the desire to experience closeness and intimacy with another human (an act forbidden in this controlled society) with the recognition of the inevitable discovery and destruction by the state is a disturbing look at the inside of a totalitarian society.  Unfortunately, it appears that this is the direction in which Western, so-called democratic and free countries are heading.  The real eye-opener is the admission by the state rulers (and torturers) that perpetuating this living hell of a society was solely to accumulate and maintain ever-increasing amounts of power.  This is a clear-eyed view of the psychopaths (like Stalin, Hitler and, quite possibly, our current governments in the West) who gain power and manipulate the system in every way possible to strive for ultimate power, with no recognition of the cost to other's lives.  This book should be on everyone's reading list as a cautionary tale about how democratic countries can be hijacked by psychopathic rulers for their own selfish accumulation of power and how fragile freedom and liberty is.
This is one of my favorite novels/essays. The characters are not extremely interesting or well developed, but the subject matter is relevant and should be studied.

review_headline: Should be compulsory reading in all high schools
review_body: If you have heard things described as Orwellian in the news or news commentary, then you need to read this book to get a true understanding of the term. It’s scary that so many predictions made in 1948 by George Orwell in his novel 1984 have come true. Some have come true in full, some in part and others, not yet realised, still have the potential to become manifest.

Many have read this classic, in my case over 50 years ago. But I read it in a different frame of mind; required reading with a test to follow.

A second read in a new era with no exterior motive made this an excellent, but disturbing read. In a new era where loss of privacy is almost taken for granted, talked about constantly, and likely to never return, this is a book to consider.
The story develops into a futuristic nightmare which is not that far from being true in some aspects, comparing to other states of fear that the world has already known. A must read.

review_headline: finally read it, and know why it made such an impact
review_body: A disturbing and well-written book, justifiably famous.  I am glad that I finally read it.  The author was also a very interesting person.
I read this book in college, but found it much more interesting & riveting with this re-reading 25 years later. Orwell was way ahead of his time.

review_headline: I should have read this long ago.
review_body: Although it isn't an easy read, aren't the best novels that way.  I find myself thinking and telling my son, this was written in 1949!  It is like a guide book for North Korea.  Shhhh, Big Brother is watching.
The was an interesting book. I would recommend it if you really want to understand what socialism is really about and how it possibly might work with a "new world order" concept.
I have always had difficulty reading this book because it's BORING.  I recommend to other bored readers and attempted readers: get over it and plow through the book for its value.

Interesting and frightening story about the ultra elite taking over the world.  The world Orwell describes in 1984 comes scarily close to North Korea of today with implications that the entire world could become like North Korea.  Many of Orwell's predictions have come true - as the NSA scans all of our communications, TV screens that can see and spy on viewers, surveillance cameras in more and more public places.  His description of continual war, fought be just a few (and drones) so that no one really cares is uncanny.  I read this book 40 years ago and thought it was far-fetched - not so today.

THIS BOOK IS DARK,  DREARY, DEPRESSING AND  SOMETIMES PREACHY.  BUT IN  THESE  TIMES WHEN SPEED AND  CONVENIENCE OFTEN SUPERSEDE PRIVACY, THIS BOOK DEFINITELY GIVES THE READER SOMETHING TO THINK ABOUT.

review_headline: This work of 'fiction' will scare you 'smart'
review_body: All one has to do is read the headlines of today... the NSA scandal, the IRS scandal, cities declaring bankruptsy and morality becoming socially unacceptable or something to be mocked.

This is an intense book but well worth the reading. It does have some material in it that is adult, I for one don't like BUT!~~ ALL in all this book really opens ones eyes to what is happening in AMERICA today and has through the years prior.

What Goverment can become if they forget it is For the People and BY the people.
A haunting cautionary tale with a gut punch of an ending. This book is a classic that is still relevant to our time. Important reading for anyone who values individuality and freedom.
Great book. Has stood the test of time. Had read it 50 years ago and it is still as good with a great twist.
Hits pretty close to home with what the governments everywhere are doing today, even though written 60 plus years ago.
I read this for the second time after several decades. It is an important read for anyone paying attention to current events and a critical read for those not yet paying attention.

Heard a zillion references to 1984 all my life, so perhaps I had too high if expectations.  Fell to sleep during a entire chapter where Winston literally reads a manifesto out loud to his girlfriend.  Frankly, I fear Big Brother more now, but because that world is lonely and boring, more so than intrusive.

Although only fully to be understood by reference to the immediate post World War II situation in which it was written, Orwell's great novel is like a lens which can be looked through both ways with equal value. One sees where his ideas may have come from in 1948...but his genius in extrapolating where they might possibly lad, not in German, nor Russian society...but in our own is horrifyingly acute. To take a quick example: aspects of newspeak clearly come from the fascist and soviet love of shortening phrases into neologisms: "Stasi" or "Comintern" surely was the genesis of MINITRU. But what would Blair have made of the instant messaging garble of our day? Our English language has indeed contracted, as he predicted so cannily. And on and on...
1984 is a great classic novel that everyone should read. A dystopian society that actually scares me a little bit.
This book was written shortly after the end of WW II and outlined the fears Orwell had for the future.  It is still thought-provoking today.

I read this in high school as a freshman and I can honestly say that I appreciate the story even more now after having revisited it years later. With the brewing conflict between the American government and the First Amendment rights of her citizens (such as drones, licence  plate scanning, and driving pattern recording) this novel by Orwell isn't just a good read, but an *important* one in the context of these future debates.

review_headline: Omg! Why did they make HS kids read this. Snore!
review_body:
I struggled at 46 to read this book. I can't imagine how my 17 year old self would have done it.
However, now that I've lived 46 years and have seen the worlds changes, wow this book, this author really had a telescope into the future.
I suggest reading it, no pushing through it just to compare Orwell's vision and how it horrifyingly matching the dircting in which our "now" world is heading.
This would be a great read if rewritten today.

Orwell's message is as timely today as it was when he first published this work. A true classic and must read.

review_headline: A book u have to read
review_body: This book should be in school to teach our kids exactly what to look out for and make sure this never happens honestly poor Winston and Julia I really wanted them to be happy together down with Big Brothe

I first heard of this book in the early 70's in high school, and discussions would ebb and flow over the years depending on current events, but I didn't buy it.  I'm glad I finally did.  Technology can work for our good or be perverted to our detriment.  This book still has a chilling impact even today.  Imagine had I read it in 1971.  I was computer savvy for the day, and although the Univac and IBM mainframes, and those dreaded punch cards(!), were hi-tech at the time along with my slide rule, today my smartphone is annoyingly smarter than me!  But, is it watching me?  No more anonymity, BIG BROTHER IS WATCHING YOU.  Are my thoughts my own or is the Thought Police hiding in the deep recesses of my brain?  Are my hopes and dreams safe?  This book is more timely now than ever before.  A very good and highly recommended read.

I'm only embarrassed I didn't read this classic sooner. After completing this novel, I suddenly found myself questioning the politics of my country and becoming a more actively involved citizen - you need to know who is pulling your strings!

review_headline: Remarkably less provocative than when I read it in High School in 1977
review_body:
I am on a kick of re-reading books that changed the way I see the world when I was younger, books like Atlas Shrugged, Brave New World and 1984 -- they're all pretty heavy-handed. To be sure, Atlas Shrugged is the worst if for no other reason than it is painfully long. But all make a sort of attempt to build a plot and sooner or later digress into some sort of manifesto. In the case of 1984, the main character finds a banned book from the leader of the resistance and several chapters of the real book are from the fictional book.

One thing I do recall from learning to write in high school and college is: show, don't tell. All of these books, in particular 1984 are pretty thin using the fiction and plot as a thin veneer over their views. In each case, they fall into long monologs or sections that suggest the author is bored of trying to present their dystopian worlds as a canvas. I would have gotten a C+ at best for any of these had I turned them in.

What's interesting to me why these books are so different now. In the case of 1984, I read it when that year was still in the future and it wasn't quite so dated. But I was also 16 and perhaps not as critical a reader as I am now. Or perhaps the end of the cold war and all that has happened since has just changed the way the world is. Or maybe in my youth or ignorance I was more tolerant of these black-and-white views of the world.

So in a way, it's worth re-reading as a way of reflection on ones past. Perhaps I won't be as disappointed as I delve back into the three books that made me appreciate literature: The Sun Also Rises, Crime and Punishment, and The Red and the Black.

review_headline: Probably One of the Best Books Ever Written
review_body: I first read this around 1984 when I was about 14.  I remember liking it a great deal, but it was a much better read as an adult.  If you haven't read it since high school, you should read it again.

It's a great read if you don't have the patience to wait just a couple more years here in the USA when you won't need to read the book, cause you will be living it.

individuality, without pleasure. An absurd absolute sadistic dictatorship like in Germany before 1945.

review_headline: A Story for our times: Majority Rule = Bolshevism = 1984
review_body:
[[ASIN:B003JTHWKU 1984]]There has been a mini-boom in the sales of Orwell's prophetic book.

Some vocabulary from the book '1984' has already entered our speech: Big Brother, Doublespeak, etc.

And no wonder, since much of the surveillance technology that Orwell wrote about is already with us.

\\"Trust me, I'm from the government,\\" is a mild form of \\"Big Brother's\\" pitch.

Of course Big Brother knows all your day to day problems: his agents watch and listen to everything. TV cameras are everywhere and your communications are intercepted.

The good and bad things in life are given new names. Good = bad & Bad = good

Some speech becomes PC (politically correct) and other speech is deleted from the language.

Orwell was certainly concerned about fascism and communism. But he was also concerned with tendencies in democracies towards suppression of minorities and their aspirations.

Orwell was not the first or the last political writer who foresaw oppression by majority rule. Alexis de Tocqueville commented on the tendency in America to conformism and to \\"majoritarianism\\", intolerance for other cultural traditions.

Virtually all political commentators saw the threat of \\"bolshevism\\", which was the Russian term for the \\"majority\\" party in the legislative assembly. Under the Communists, \\"Bolshevism\\" stood for the \\"dictatorship of the majority\\", another term for the dictatorship of the proletariat. Majoritarianism. Totalitarian democracy.

Both De Tocqueville and Orwell saw the risk of \\"democracy\\" becoming \\"majoritarianism\\" and then evolving into \\"totalitarian democracy\\".

The framers of the US Bill of Rights saw this danger too and added to the Constitution the safeguards that once served to make America a beacon for the rest of the world.

1984 is a book worth reading because it shows how everything can go wrong when people place too much trust in Big Brother.

Terrorism? Big Brother says that's what the bad guys do. We bomb people in far off places to make the world safe for democracy. The old and sick and women and children die when we sent in the drones. They just happened to sit down to dinner in the wrong place at the wrong time. Some \\"collateral damage\\" happens.

Spying? Big Brother says we spy only on foreign bad guys who contact local bad guys. If you are innocent, you don't have to worry.

Orwell knew his history.

When they came for the gypsies, I didn't protest because I'm not a gypsy.
When they came for the anarchists, I didn't protest because I'm not an anarchist.
When they came for the Jews, I didn't protest because I'm not a Jew.
But when they came for me, I saw there was nobody left in my street to protest. So they took me away.

1984 is a book for our times because it shows us that the price of liberty is eternal vigilance.

We can see in this book how important it is to control technology to prevent its abuse. Otherwise elites in modern democracies will subvert constitutional safeguards by stealth, by smooth promises, and by offering security from outside threats both real and invented.

By giving power to one group or man, 1984 becomes a transcript of future events.
Everyone should read this book: it should be required reading in school. Orwell gives us a convincing view of what our society can become if we continue to believe in government infallibility,

review_headline: Year was wrong... That is all
review_body: Loved it when I read it as a rebellious teen and now that we are actually LIVING 1984, it is a reminder of simpler times. I picked this up after I read an article that stated sales of this book had risen dramatically in recent weeks, i was on sale for $0.99 so a bargain anyway. Others have said it better, but if the American government scares you now, just wait until you read this.

It will be obvious that many stories and myths have risen from the pages of this book... and what's worse, many of its pages contain visions that stare us in the face daily. Is not the iPad I'm writing this review on, a *perfect* implementation of a mobile telescreen, with its forward facing camera? Is the country of North Korea much different in policy than Oceania?

This work of fiction could just as easily be a docu-drama based on the world we live in... I have no idea how it took me until 32 years of age to read it. This should be required in high school reading

Must read.
Scary parallels between some of the blindly faithful followers in the book and those following the duopoly that exists today.
I got this book for my mom.  so she can see what may be going on in this country and to keep herself informed.
How could you not be entertained by Orwell's 1984.  I re-read this every five years or so and never get tired of it.

Not at all what I thought it would be based on cultural references. An exploration of how fragile and malleable our minds are. The analogies to modern times I expected were not there, but the more deeply seditious way we control each other's minds is well portrayed.

Though this was written long, long ago, it contains a message that is still timely today.  The first time I read it, I assumed that it was to point out the dangers of Communism; now I realize that it is about mind control and how people respond to it.  I would recommend it to anyone. Patricia
